template.desc:
Hybrid network connectivity from a data center to the AWS Cloud

For reliable and stable latency connectivity from countries without AWS Region or Local Zones to AWS Regions in the EU, AWS recommends using AWS Direct Connect (with MACSec or AWS Site-to-site VPN for additional data in transit security).

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-315
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-315: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in a Cookie The product stores sensitive information in cleartext in a cookie. Attackers can use widely-available tools to view the cookie and read the sensitive information. Even if the information is encoded in a way that is not human-readable, certain techniques could determine which encoding is being used, then decode the information.

weakness.name: CWE-352
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-384
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-384: Session Fixation Authenticating a user, or otherwise establishing a new user session, without invalidating any existing session identifier gives an attacker the opportunity to steal authenticated sessions.

weakness.name: CWE-404
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-404: Improper Resource Shutdown or Release The product does not release or incorrectly releases a resource before it is made available for re-use. When a resource is created or allocated, the developer is responsible for properly releasing the resource as well as accounting for all potential paths of expiration or invalidation, such as a set period of time or revocation.

weakness.name: CWE-434
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

weakness.name: CWE-664
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-664: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime The product does not maintain or incorrectly maintains control over a resource throughout its lifetime of creation, use, and release.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-862
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-862: Missing Authorization The product does not perform an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

countermeasure.name: Enforce minimal privilege security group rules
countermeasure.desc: To minimize vulnerabilities in AWS EC2 environments, configure security groups with the least permissive rules necessary for operational functionality. Start by defining default deny-all inbound and outbound rules, and then explicitly allow only the required traffic based on the application's needs. Regularly review and update these rules to adapt to changing network requirements and to close any gaps that may arise due to evolving threat landscapes. This approach ensures a strict security posture by limiting potential entry points for attackers.

countermeasure.name: Implement EC2 Auto Scaling with Elastic IP for resilience
countermeasure.desc: Enhance the resilience and availability of your AWS EC2 instances by implementing Auto Scaling in conjunction with Elastic IP addresses. Auto Scaling ensures that your application maintains the desired performance and availability levels by automatically adjusting the number of EC2 instances. Pair this with Elastic IP addresses to maintain a consistent public IP address during instance failure and recovery, facilitating seamless failover and minimizing downtime. Set up Auto Scaling policies based on specific metrics that reflect your application's needs to automate scaling actions.

countermeasure.name: Implement identity federation for secure access management
countermeasure.desc: Enhance security and streamline access management in AWS EC2 by implementing identity federation using trusted identity providers and AWS IAM roles. This approach delegates authentication to external identity providers, reducing the need for multiple credentials and centralizing user access control. Set up IAM roles to define and enforce policy-based permissions that grant least privilege access to EC2 resources. Regularly review and update IAM policies and trust relationships to adapt to changes in your operational environment.

countermeasure.name: Implement multi-zone deployment for critical components
countermeasure.desc: To maximize fault tolerance and ensure high availability of your application, deploy critical components across multiple AWS Availability Zones. This approach provides redundancy by distributing resources geographically, reducing the impact of zone-specific failures. Configure each component to operate independently in each zone, and utilize load balancing to manage traffic across zones effectively. Regularly test the setup to ensure that failover processes work seamlessly and that there are no single points of failure.

countermeasure.name: Leverage AWS Trusted Advisor for continuous improvement
countermeasure.desc: Utilize AWS Trusted Advisor to regularly inspect your AWS environment for potential cost optimizations and security enhancements. This service provides real-time insights into your configurations, highlighting opportunities for improvement and alerting you to potential security risks. Implement the recommendations provided by Trusted Advisor to refine resource utilization, reduce costs, and bolster your security posture. Schedule periodic reviews of Trusted Advisor findings to ensure your AWS deployments remain aligned with best practices.

Utilize the AWS Service Quotas console or API to track current usage and compare it against the available limits. Plan and request quota increases well in advance of anticipated need to avoid service disruptions. This proactive approach helps in maintaining continuous service performance and scaling readiness as your application grows.

Set appropriate TTL values based on your network architecture to ensure that packets do not expire prematurely during transit. Regularly review and adjust these TTL settings to adapt to any changes in network path or infrastructure, ensuring optimal performance and security.

Set up automated snapshots and AMI generation based on a schedule that aligns with your business's risk tolerance and operational requirements.

countermeasure.name: Regular OS and application updates
countermeasure.desc: Consistently apply patches and updates to the operating systems and applications on your AWS EC2 instances to mitigate vulnerabilities. Establish a regular update schedule and use automation tools to apply these updates across your infrastructure. Ensure that all systems are covered by using centralized management tools, and conduct vulnerability assessments after updates to verify that no new exposures have been introduced.

countermeasure.name: Routine testing of EC2 recovery procedures
countermeasure.desc: Implement a regular testing schedule for the recovery processes of your AWS EC2 instances and Amazon EBS volumes to ensure that data and services can be effectively restored after an outage. This practice involves simulating failure scenarios and monitoring the recovery process to verify that all data integrity and functionalities are maintained post-recovery. Adjust recovery strategies based on test outcomes to enhance resilience and minimize downtime.

countermeasure.name: Secure data with EBS encryption
countermeasure.desc: Ensure the security of sensitive data stored at rest by enabling encryption on Amazon EBS volumes and snapshots. Use AWS Key Management Service (KMS) to manage the encryption keys and automate the encryption process for both new and existing volumes. This step protects data from unauthorized access and meets compliance requirements for data protection. Regularly audit your encryption and key management practices to maintain robust security standards.

countermeasure.name: Segregate EBS volumes for OS and data
countermeasure.desc: To enhance data resilience and recovery in AWS EC2, configure separate Amazon EBS volumes for the operating system and application data. This segregation ensures that data can be retained even after an instance is terminated, facilitating easier backup processes and faster recovery operations. Regularly verify that the data volume is set to persist independently of the instance lifecycle settings to prevent accidental data loss.

countermeasure.name: Utilize EC2 instance store for temporary data
countermeasure.desc: Implement the use of EC2 instance store volumes for storing temporary data that requires low latency access and does not need to be durable across instance stops or terminations. Incorporate data replication strategies across multiple instances or availability zones to ensure fault tolerance and data availability. This approach leverages the high-performance characteristics of instance stores while mitigating the risk of data loss due to instance failure. Regularly evaluate and update your replication strategies to maintain system resilience and data integrity.

reference.name: Best practices for Amazon EC2

countermeasure.name: Utilize EC2 metadata and tagging for resource management
countermeasure.desc: Implement a robust tagging strategy using instance metadata and custom tags to effectively track and manage AWS EC2 resources. Define and enforce a consistent tagging schema that includes critical details such as owner, environment, and purpose for each instance. Utilize these tags to automate management tasks, enforce security policies, and simplify cost allocation and reporting. Regularly audit your tagging strategy to ensure compliance and optimize resource tracking.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Resource mismanagement
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Resource mismanagement in AWS EC2 encompasses the improper allocation, oversight, and operation of EC2 resources. This can include inefficient use of computing power, storage, and network configurations, leading to increased costs and reduced system performance.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Primary agents include internal misconfigurations, lack of resource oversight, and inadequate scaling strategies which may fail to meet system demands or optimize costs effectively.

Impacts

Consequences of resource mismanagement can include overspending, performance bottlenecks, and potential service interruptions, all of which can negatively affect the operational efficiency and economic viability of the system.

Example Attack Scenarios

A typical scenario might involve an organization that has over-provisioned EC2 instances without proper load balancing or auto-scaling configurations. This results in high operational costs and underutilized resources, impacting the budget and overall system efficiency.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Failover and recovery issues
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Failover and recovery issues in AWS EC2 pertain to the challenges and failures that can arise during the process of recovering from hardware or software failures. Proper management is crucial to ensure continuous availability and data integrity.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main agents include system malfunctions, configuration errors, and external disruptions that impact the EC2 environment. These can be exacerbated by inadequate redundancy planning or flawed recovery procedures.

Impacts

Ineffective failover and recovery strategies can lead to significant service disruptions, data loss, and prolonged downtime, affecting business operations and trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

A scenario could involve an EC2 instance failing to switch over to a standby in another Availability Zone due to misconfigured failover processes. This results in an outage, where critical applications remain offline until manual intervention is performed, leading to potential data loss and service disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Inadequate access controls
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Inadequate access controls in AWS EC2 involve insufficient management of permissions and access rights to EC2 resources, which can expose sensitive data and computing processes to unauthorized users or malicious entities.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include unauthorized users who may exploit weak authentication and authorization processes to gain access to EC2 instances. Misconfigured IAM roles and security group settings are common vectors.

Impacts

The consequences can range from data breaches and unauthorized system modifications to complete system takeover, compromising data integrity and organizational security.

Example Attack Scenarios

An example scenario could involve an attacker exploiting overly permissive IAM role configurations to access and manipulate EC2 instances. This unauthorized access could lead to data leakage, system disruptions, or the deployment of malicious software within the network.

threat.name: System vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

System Vulnerabilities in AWS EC2 refer to weaknesses in the EC2 infrastructure that can be exploited by attackers. These vulnerabilities may stem from outdated software, misconfigured systems, or inherent security flaws.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers and malicious insiders who exploit these vulnerabilities through malware, social engineering, or direct system attacks.

Impacts

The impacts of system vulnerabilities can be severe, including unauthorized data access, system downtime, and compromised data integrity and confidentiality.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker discovers an unpatched vulnerability in an EC2 instances operating system. They exploit this flaw to gain unauthorized access and install ransomware, leading to data encryption and a demand for payment to restore access.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1133 - External Remote Services

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data breach and loss
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data Breach and Loss in AWS EC2 encompasses unauthorized access and unintended exposure or destruction of data stored on EC2 instances. These incidents can occur due to a variety of security lapses or system failures.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include hackers exploiting security vulnerabilities, insiders abusing their access rights, or accidental exposures due to misconfigurations. Common vectors are compromised credentials, malware, or poorly secured API endpoints.

Impacts

Impacts range from the loss of sensitive or proprietary information to regulatory non-compliance and reputational damage, which can result in significant financial costs.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker uses stolen credentials to access an EC2 instance and exfiltrates databases containing personal customer information, resulting in a data breach that violates privacy laws and leads to financial penalties and loss of customer trust.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

threat.name: Network security issues
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Network security issues in AWS EC2 involve vulnerabilities that affect the network layer, exposing EC2 instances to unauthorized access or data interception. These can result from improper security configurations, weak network protocols, or inadequate encryption practices.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Common agents include external attackers and malicious insiders utilizing tools like packet sniffers, man-in-the-middle attacks, or exploiting public-facing APIs.

Impacts

The impacts include data theft, compromised system integrity, and potential service disruptions, leading to operational and financial losses.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker performs a man-in-the-middle attack on unencrypted network communication between EC2 instances, capturing sensitive data transmitted over the network. This breach could result in significant data leakage, including customer information or proprietary business data.

weakness.name: CWE-1125
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1125: Excessive Attack Surface The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-352
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Consider encryption of data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
You have the following options for protecting data at rest in Amazon S3:

  • Server-side encryption All Amazon S3 buckets have encryption configured by default, and all new objects that are uploaded to an S3 bucket are automatically encrypted at rest. Server-side encryption with Amazon S3 managed keys (SSE-S3) is the default encryption configuration for every bucket in Amazon S3. To use a different type of encryption, you can either specify the type of server-side encryption to use in your S3 PUT requests, or you can set the default encryption configuration in the destination bucket.

Amazon S3 also provides these server-side encryption options:

  • Server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (SSE-KMS)
  • Dual-layer server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (DSSE-KMS)
  • Server-side encryption with customer-provided keys (SSE-C)

For more information, see Protecting data with server-side encryption.

  • Client-side encryption Encrypt data client-side and upload the encrypted data to Amazon S3. In this case, you manage the encryption process, the encryption keys, and related tools. As with server-side encryption, client-side encryption can help reduce risk by encrypting the data with a key that is stored in a different mechanism than the mechanism that stores the data itself.

Amazon S3 provides multiple client-side encryption options. For more information, see Protecting data by using client-side encryption.

countermeasure.name: Consider using S3 Cross-Region Replication
countermeasure.desc:
Although Amazon S3 stores your data across multiple geographically diverse Availability Zones by default, compliance requirements might dictate that you store data at even greater distances. With S3 Cross-Region Replication (CRR), you can replicate data between distant AWS Regions to help satisfy these requirements. CRR enables automatic, asynchronous copying of objects across buckets in different AWS Regions. For more information, see Replicating objects.

Note

CRR requires both the source and destination S3 buckets to have versioning enabled.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-replication-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

countermeasure.name: Consider using S3 Object Lock
countermeasure.desc:
With S3 Object Lock, you can store objects by using a "Write Once Read Many" (WORM) model. S3 Object Lock can help prevent accidental or inappropriate deletion of data. For example, you can use S3 Object Lock to help protect your AWS CloudTrail logs.

For more information, see Using S3 Object Lock.

countermeasure.name: Disable access control lists (ACLs) and use bucket policies to manage permissions
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Object Ownership is an Amazon S3 bucket-level setting that you can use to control ownership of objects uploaded to your bucket and to disable or enable ACLs. By default, Object Ownership is set to the Bucket owner enforced setting and all ACLs are disabled. When ACLs are disabled, the bucket owner owns all the objects in the bucket and manages access to data exclusively using access management policies.

A majority of modern use cases in Amazon S3 no longer require the use of access control lists (ACLs). We recommend that you disable ACLs, except in unusual circumstances where you must control access for each object individually. To disable ACLs and take ownership of every object in your bucket, apply the bucket owner enforced setting for S3 Object Ownership. When you disable ACLs, you can easily maintain a bucket with objects uploaded by different AWS accounts.

When ACLs are disabled access control for your data is based on policies, such as the following:

  • AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) user policies
  • S3 bucket policies
  • Virtual private cloud (VPC) endpoint policies
  • AWS Organizations service control policies (SCPs)

Disabling ACLs simplifies permissions management and auditing. ACLs are disabled for new buckets by default. You can also disable ACLs for existing buckets. If you have an existing bucket that already has objects in it, after you disable ACLs, the object and bucket ACLs are no longer part of the access-evaluation process. Instead, access is granted or denied on the basis of policies.

Before you disable ACLs, make sure that you do the following:

  • Review your bucket policy to ensure that it covers all the ways that you intend to grant access to your bucket outside of your account.
  • Reset your bucket ACL to the default (full control to the bucket owner).

After you disable ACLs, the following behaviors occur:

  • Your bucket accepts only PUT requests that do not specify an ACL or PUT requests with bucket owner full control ACLs. These ACLs include the bucket-owner-full-control canned ACL or equivalent forms of this ACL that are expressed in XML.
  • Existing applications that support bucket owner full control ACLs see no impact.
  • PUT requests that contain other ACLs (for example, custom grants to certain AWS accounts) fail and return an HTTP status code 400 (Bad Request) with the error code AccessControlListNotSupported.

For more information, see Controlling ownership of objects and disabling ACLs for your bucket.

countermeasure.name: Discover sensitive data by using Amazon Macie
countermeasure.desc:
Amazon Macie is a security service that discovers sensitive data by using machine learning and pattern matching. Macie provides visibility into data security risks, and enables automated protection against those risks. With Macie, you can automate the discovery and reporting of sensitive data in your Amazon S3 data estate to gain a better understanding of the data that your organization stores in S3.

To detect sensitive data with Macie, you can use built-in criteria and techniques that are designed to detect a large and growing list of sensitive data types for many countries and regions. These sensitive data types include multiple types of personally identifiable information (PII), financial data, and credentials data. You can also use custom criteria that you defineregular expressions that define text patterns to match and, optionally, character sequences and proximity rules that refine the results.

If Macie detects sensitive data in an S3 object, Macie generates a security finding to notify you. This finding provides information about the affected object, the types and number of occurrences of the sensitive data that Macie found, and additional details to help you investigate the affected S3 bucket and object. For more information, see the Amazon Macie User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS Config
countermeasure.desc:
Several of the best practices listed in this topic suggest creating AWS Config rules. AWS Config helps you to assess, audit, and evaluate the configurations of your AWS resources. AWS Config monitors resource configurations so that you can evaluate the recorded configurations against the desired secure configurations. With AWS Config, you can do the following:

  • Review changes in configurations and relationships between AWS resources
  • Investigate detailed resource-configuration histories
  • Determine your overall compliance against the configurations specified in your internal guidelines

Using AWS Config can help you simplify compliance auditing, security analysis, change management, and operational troubleshooting. For more information, see Setting Up AWS Config with the Console in the AWS Config Developer Guide. When specifying the resource types to record, ensure that you include Amazon S3 resources.

Important

AWS Config managed rules only supports general purpose buckets when evaluating Amazon S3 resources. AWS Config doesnt record configuration changes for directory buckets. For more information, see AWS Config Managed Rules and List of AWS Config Managed Rules in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

For an example of how to use AWS Config, see How to Use AWS Config to Monitor for and Respond to Amazon S3 Buckets Allowing Public Access on the AWS Security Blog.

countermeasure.name: Enable S3 versioning
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Versioning is a means of keeping multiple variants of an object in the same bucket. You can use versioning to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your bucket. With versioning, you can easily recover from both unintended user actions and application failures.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-versioning-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

For more information, see Using versioning in S3 buckets.

countermeasure.name: Enforce encryption of data in transit
countermeasure.desc:
You can use HTTPS (TLS) to help prevent potential attackers from eavesdropping on or manipulating network traffic by using person-in-the-middle or similar attacks. We recommend allowing only encrypted connections over HTTPS (TLS) by using the aws:SecureTransport condition in your Amazon S3 bucket policies.

Important

We recommend that your application not pin Amazon S3 TLS certificates as AWS doesnt support pinning of publicly-trusted certificates. S3 automatically renews certificates and renewal can happen any time before certificate expiry. Renewing a certificate generates a new public-private key pair. If youve pinned an S3 certificate which has been recently renewed with a new public key, you wont be able to connect to S3 until your application uses the new certificate.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-ssl-requests-only managed AWS Config rule.

countermeasure.name: Ensure that your Amazon S3 buckets use the correct policies and are not publicly accessible
countermeasure.desc:
Unless you explicitly require anyone on the internet to be able to read or write to your S3 bucket, make sure that your S3 bucket is not public. The following are some of the steps that you can take to block public access:

  • Use S3 Block Public Access. With S3 Block Public Access, you can easily set up centralized controls to limit public access to your Amazon S3 resources. These centralized controls are enforced regardless of how the resources are created. For more information, see Blocking public access to your Amazon S3 storage.
  • Identify Amazon S3 bucket policies that allow a wildcard identity such as "Principal": "*" (which effectively means "anyone"). Also look for policies that allow a wildcard action "*" (which effectively allows the user to perform any action in the Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Similarly, look for Amazon S3 bucket access control lists (ACLs) that provide read, write, or full-access to "Everyone" or "Any authenticated AWS user."
  • Use the ListBuckets API operation to scan all of your Amazon S3 buckets. Then use GetBucketAcl, GetBucketWebsite, and GetBucketPolicy to determine whether each bucket has compliant access controls and a compliant configuration.
  • Use AWS Trusted Advisor to inspect your Amazon S3 implementation.
  • Consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-public-read-prohibited and s3-bucket-public-write-prohibited managed AWS Config Rules.

For more information, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Identify and audit all of your Amazon S3 buckets
countermeasure.desc:
Identification of your IT assets is a crucial aspect of governance and security. You need to have visibility of all your Amazon S3 resources to assess their security posture and take action on potential areas of weakness. To audit your resources, we recommend doing the following:

  • Use Tag Editor to identify and tag security-sensitive or audit-sensitive resources, then use those tags when you need to search for these resources. For more information, see Searching for Resources to Tag in the Tagging AWS Resources User Guide.
  • Use S3 Inventory to audit and report on the replication and encryption status of your objects for business, compliance, and regulatory needs. For more information, see Amazon S3 Inventory.
  • Create resource groups for your Amazon S3 resources. For more information, see What are resource groups? in the AWS Resource Groups User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Identify potential threats to your Amazon S3 buckets by using Amazon GuardDuty
countermeasure.desc: Amazon GuardDuty is a threat detection service that identifies potential threats to your accounts, containers, workloads, and the data within your AWS environment. By using machine learning (ML) models, and anomaly and threat detection capabilities, Amazon GuardDuty continuously monitors different data sources to identify and prioritize potential security risks and malicious activities in your environment. When you enable GuardDuty, it offers threat detection for foundational data sources that includes AWS CloudTrail management events, VPC flow logs, and DNS logs. To extend threat detection to data plane events in S3 buckets, you can enable the GuardDuty S3 Protection feature. This feature detects threats such as data exfiltration and suspicious access to S3 buckets via Tor nodes. GuardDuty also establishes a normal baseline pattern in your environment and when it identifies a potentially anomalous behavior, it provides contextual information to help you remediate the potentially compromised S3 bucket or AWS credentials. For more information, see GuardDuty.

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege access
countermeasure.desc:
When granting permissions, you decide who is getting what permissions to which Amazon S3 resources. You enable specific actions that you want to allow on those resources. Therefore, we recommend that you grant only the permissions that are required to perform a task. Implementing least privilege access is fundamental in reducing security risk and the impact that could result from errors or malicious intent.

The following tools are available to implement least privilege access:

  • Policy actions for Amazon S3 and Permissions Boundaries for IAM Entities
  • How Amazon S3 works with IAM
  • Access control list (ACL) overview
  • Service Control Policies

For guidance on what to consider when choosing one or more of the preceding mechanisms, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Implement monitoring by using AWS monitoring tools
countermeasure.desc:
Monitoring is an important part of maintaining the reliability, security, availability, and performance of Amazon S3 and your AWS solutions. AWS provides several tools and services to help you monitor Amazon S3 and your other AWS services. For example, you can monitor Amazon CloudWatch metrics for Amazon S3, particularly the PutRequests, GetRequests, 4xxErrors, and DeleteRequests metrics. For more information, see Monitoring metrics with Amazon CloudWatch and Monitoring Amazon S3.

For a second example, see Example: Amazon S3 Bucket Activity. This example describes how to create a CloudWatch alarm that is triggered when an Amazon S3 API call is made to PUT or DELETE a bucket policy, a bucket lifecycle, or a bucket replication configuration, or to PUT a bucket ACL.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
AWS CloudTrail provides a record of actions taken by a user, a role, or an AWS service in Amazon S3. You can use information collected by CloudTrail to determine the following:

  • The request that was made to Amazon S3
  • The IP address from which the request was made
  • Who made the request
  • When the request was made
  • Additional details about the request

For example, you can identify CloudTrail entries for PUT actions that affect data access, in particular PutBucketAcl, PutObjectAcl, PutBucketPolicy, and PutBucketWebsite.

When you set up your AWS account, CloudTrail is enabled by default. You can view recent events in the CloudTrail console. To create an ongoing record of activity and events for your Amazon S3 buckets, you can create a trail in the CloudTrail console. For more information, see Logging data events in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.

When you create a trail, you can configure CloudTrail to log data events. Data events are records of resource operations performed on or within a resource. In Amazon S3, data events record object-level API activity for individual buckets. CloudTrail supports a subset of Amazon S3 object-level API operations, such as GetObject, DeleteObject, and PutObject. For more information about how CloudTrail works with Amazon S3, see Logging Amazon S3 API calls using AWS CloudTrail. In the Amazon S3 console, you can also configure your S3 buckets to Enabling CloudTrail event logging for S3 buckets and objects.

AWS Config provides a managed rule (cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled) that you can use to confirm that at least one CloudTrail trail is logging data events for your S3 buckets. For more information, see cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM roles for applications and AWS services that require Amazon S3 access
countermeasure.desc:
In order for applications running on Amazon EC2 or other AWS services to access Amazon S3 resources, they must include valid AWS credentials in their AWS API requests. We recommend not storing AWS credentials directly in the application or Amazon EC2 instance. These are long-term credentials that are not automatically rotated and could have a significant business impact if they are compromised.

Instead, use an IAM role to manage temporary credentials for applications or services that need to access Amazon S3. When you use a role, you don't have to distribute long-term credentials (such as a username and password or access keys) to an Amazon EC2 instance or AWS service, such as AWS Lambda. The role supplies temporary permissions that applications can use when they make calls to other AWS resources.

For more information, see the following topics in the IAM User Guide:

  • IAM Roles
  • Common Scenarios for Roles: Users, Applications, and Services

countermeasure.name: Use S3 Storage Lens
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Storage Lens is a cloud-storage analytics feature that you can use to gain organization-wide visibility into object-storage usage and activity. S3 Storage Lens also analyzes metrics to deliver contextual recommendations that you can use to optimize storage costs and apply best practices for protecting your data.

With S3 Storage Lens, you can use metrics to generate summary insights, such as finding out how much storage you have across your entire organization or which are the fastest-growing buckets and prefixes. You can also use S3 Storage Lens metrics to identify cost-optimization opportunities, implement data-protection and access-management best practices, and improve the performance of application workloads.

For example, you can identify buckets that don't have S3 Lifecycle rules to abort incomplete multipart uploads that are more than 7 days old. You can also identify buckets that aren't following data-protection best practices, such as using S3 Replication or S3 Versioning. For more information, see Understanding Amazon S3 Storage Lens.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized extraction of sensitive data from S3 buckets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data stored in Amazon S3 buckets may be extracted without proper oversight due to inadequate monitoring and insufficient access controls. This can lead to unauthorized data access, leaks, and breaches, compromising the integrity and confidentiality of the data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include malicious insiders, external attackers, and compromised accounts. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak access controls, lack of encryption, and insufficient logging and monitoring mechanisms, allowing undetected data exfiltration.

Impacts

Impacts include severe data breaches, loss of intellectual property, financial losses, legal consequences due to non-compliance with data protection regulations, and damage to an organization's reputation and customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An insider with access to an S3 bucket containing sensitive customer information downloads the data without being detected due to a lack of proper monitoring and oversight.
  2. An external attacker compromises an employee's AWS credentials and uses them to extract sensitive data from an S3 bucket, leading to a significant data breach and regulatory fines.
  3. Sensitive financial data stored in an S3 bucket is exfiltrated by an attacker exploiting overly permissive access controls, resulting in the exposure of confidential business information and competitive disadvantage.
  4. A lack of proper logging and alerting mechanisms allows an attacker to continuously extract small amounts of sensitive data over an extended period, going unnoticed until the breach is discovered during an audit.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1011 - Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Inadequate monitoring of S3 buckets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

The lack of adequate monitoring of Amazon S3 buckets can result in undetected data breaches or data loss. Without proper logging, alerting, and monitoring mechanisms, unauthorized access or malicious activities can go unnoticed, leading to severe security and compliance issues.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and compromised accounts. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak or non-existent monitoring systems, allowing attackers to access, modify, or extract data without detection.

Impacts

Impacts include significant data breaches, loss of sensitive and critical data, non-compliance with regulatory requirements, financial losses, and damage to the organization's reputation and customer trust. The inability to detect and respond to security incidents in a timely manner exacerbates these risks.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to an S3 bucket and exfiltrates sensitive data over time. Due to inadequate monitoring, the breach remains undetected until the data is leaked or sold on the dark web, resulting in a major security incident.
  2. An insider with malicious intent deletes critical business data from an S3 bucket. Without proper monitoring and alerting mechanisms, the data loss is not identified until business operations are disrupted, causing significant financial and operational impacts.
  3. During a routine compliance audit, an organization discovers that an S3 bucket containing regulated data has been accessed by unauthorized users multiple times over the past year, leading to substantial fines and legal consequences.
  4. A lack of detailed logging and alerting allows an attacker to use compromised credentials to make unauthorized changes to an S3 bucket policy, granting themselves ongoing access and leading to a prolonged data breach that goes unnoticed for months.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure S3 bucket configurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Amazon S3 buckets that are not properly secured may be accessible by unauthorized users. This can result from misconfigured permissions, lack of encryption, and absence of stringent access controls, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized data access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and automated bots scanning for misconfigured buckets. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak or incorrect bucket policies, overly permissive access controls, and publicly accessible buckets without proper security measures.

Impacts

Impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, loss of intellectual property, compliance violations, financial penalties, and damage to the organization's reputation. Misconfigured buckets can also lead to data manipulation or deletion, further compromising data integrity and availability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An S3 bucket containing confidential customer data is mistakenly configured with public read access, allowing anyone on the internet to access and download sensitive information, resulting in a significant data breach.
  2. During a routine security scan, it is discovered that several S3 buckets are accessible to unauthorized internal users due to misconfigured IAM policies, leading to unauthorized access and potential data leaks.
  3. An external attacker uses automated tools to identify and access an S3 bucket that has been inadvertently left publicly accessible. The attacker exfiltrates proprietary business information, causing financial and reputational damage to the company.
  4. A developer unintentionally grants write permissions to all authenticated AWS users on an S3 bucket, allowing unauthorized users to upload malicious content or delete critical data, leading to operational disruptions and potential legal issues.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-682
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-682: Incorrect Calculation The product performs a calculation that generates incorrect or unintended results that are later used in security-critical decisions or resource management. When product performs a security-critical calculation incorrectly, it might lead to incorrect resource allocations, incorrect privilege assignments, or failed comparisons among other things. Many of the direct results of an incorrect calculation can lead to even larger problems such as failed protection mechanisms or even arbitrary code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-697
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-697: Incorrect Comparison The product compares two entities in a security-relevant context, but the comparison is incorrect, which may lead to resultant weaknesses.

countermeasure.name: Adopt capacity-aware, multi-Availability Zone placement strategies
countermeasure.desc:
Step-by-Step Guidance for Implementing the Countermeasure:

1. Use Multiple Instance Types and Launch Templates

To reduce potential disruptions caused by infrastructure limitations within a single Availability Zone (AZ), leverage multiple EC2 instance types and launch templates:

  • Analyze workload requirements to select compatible EC2 instance families/types that meet compute, memory, storage, and networking needs.
  • Create launch templates for each instance type, specifying key configuration details such as AMI, instance type, security group, and block device mappings. Follow AWS Launch Template Guidance for detailed instructions.
  • Test launch templates in your development environment to confirm compatibility and performance.

2. Configure Auto Scaling Groups Across Multiple Availability Zone Subnets

To achieve high availability and fault tolerance, distribute workloads across multiple subnets tied to different AZs.

  • Identify subnets associated with distinct AZs within your VPC. Ensure your VPC is configured correctly (Subnet Documentation).
  • Create or update Auto Scaling Groups (ASGs) to span these subnets, specifying multiple AZs during ASG configuration.
  • Set ASG scaling policies based on workload demand or health checks to dynamically allocate resources.

3. Monitor and Plan Service Quotas Per Availability Zone

AWS imposes quotas on resources per region and AZ, which can lead to capacity constraints. To avoid service disruptions:

  • Use the AWS Service Quotas dashboard to monitor quotas for critical resources like EC2 instances, EBS volumes, and Elastic IPs.
  • Plan resource allocations carefully while scaling across AZs and request quota increases as needed using AWS Service Quotas Console.
  • Automate monitoring of service quotas using Amazon CloudWatch.

4. Validate That Critical Workloads Can Start in Alternate Availability Zones

Ensure failover capabilities for critical workloads in case one AZ becomes unavailable:

  • Test the deployment of your applications in alternate AZs by simulating failure scenarios.
  • Review resource dependencies (e.g., EBS volumes and IP addresses) and ensure configurations allow for quick replication or reassignment in another AZ.
  • Create Disaster Recovery (DR) plans to guide workloads' transition within minutes of AZ disruptions.

5. Continuously Evaluate and Audit Configuration

Regularly audit your architecture and workload distribution across AZs to identify security and operational risks.

  • Use AWS Config to set up rules for continuous compliance checks.
  • Review AWS Trusted Advisor recommendations to optimize availability configurations and verify AZ balance.
  • Conduct routine penetration testing and failure drills for detecting vulnerabilities and validating failover mechanisms.

References

  • AWS EC2 Availability Zones Documentation
  • AWS Global Infrastructure
  • AWS EC2 Launch Templates
  • AWS Service Quotas
  • Amazon CloudWatch
  • AWS Config

countermeasure.name: Constrain egress per Availability Zone using NAT, routes, and endpoints
countermeasure.desc:
Step 1: Deploy NAT Gateways Per Availability Zone

To ensure high availability and fault tolerance, deploy a NAT Gateway in each Availability Zone within your VPC.

  • Navigate to the Amazon VPC console.
  • In the navigation pane, select NAT Gateways and then click Create NAT Gateway.
  • Select the subnet corresponding to the Availability Zone where the NAT Gateway will reside.
  • Allocate or select an Elastic IP address to associate with the NAT Gateway.
  • Repeat this process for all relevant Availability Zones in your VPC.

Step 2: Bind Private Subnets to Same-Zone NAT Gateways

Assign route tables to private subnets and ensure traffic destined for the internet is routed through NAT Gateways in the same Availability Zone.

  • In the Amazon VPC console, select Route Tables.
  • Choose a route table associated with a private subnet.
  • Edit routes to add a destination of 0.0.0.0/0 and set the target to the NAT Gateway's ID specific to the same Availability Zone.
  • Associate the route table with the private subnet in the Subnet Associations tab.
  • Repeat these steps for all private subnets to ensure zonal redundancy.

Step 3: Restrict Egress with Route Tables and Network ACLs

Limit the outbound traffic from private subnets to the minimum necessary to reduce the attack surface.

  • Configure the route table to direct only necessary traffic to specific destinations via the NAT Gateway.
  • Set up Network ACLs (NACLs) to explicitly allow specific protocols, ports, and IP ranges necessary for your applications.
  • Ensure a default "Deny" rule for other outbound traffic.

Step 4: Prefer VPC Endpoints for AWS Service Traffic

Leverage VPC endpoints (interface or gateway endpoints) to route traffic to AWS services directly within the AWS network, avoiding public internet routes.

  • Navigate to the Amazon VPC console and select Endpoints.
  • Click Create Endpoint and select the desired AWS service, such as S3 or DynamoDB.
  • Choose the appropriate Endpoint type (gateway or interface) based on the service.
  • Associate the endpoint with the relevant route tables within your VPC.
  • Test and verify traffic to AWS services flows through the endpoint instead of the NAT Gateway.

References

  • VPC Security Best Practices
  • Amazon VPC NAT Gateway Documentation
  • Amazon VPC Endpoints Documentation
  • Network ACLs Documentation

countermeasure.name: Design multi-Availability Zone architectures for fault isolation
countermeasure.desc:
To improve the security and resiliency of your workload in AWS, follow the step-by-step guidance below for distributing critical resources across multiple Availability Zones (AZs):

  1. Determine the number of Availability Zones and Regions: Analyze the workload requirements to identify suitable AWS Regions and the number of Availability Zones available in each Region. Refer to the AWS Availability Zone documentation to find detailed information.
  2. Create separate subnets for each Availability Zone: Design your Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) with subnets distributed across multiple AZs. Each AZ should have a dedicated subnet to ensure proper resource isolation and failover capabilities. Follow the guidelines in the AWS VPC User Guide for subnet creation.
  3. Configure Auto Scaling Groups across multiple subnets: Create an Auto Scaling Group (ASG) and specify the subnets in multiple AZs to ensure instances can launch in alternative AZs during an outage. Enable dynamic scaling policies to maintain a consistent level of performance. Review the AWS Auto Scaling documentation for step-by-step setup instructions.
  4. Use Multi-AZ deployments for managed services: For database services like Amazon RDS, enable Multi-AZ deployment to provision a standby replica in a secondary AZ. This setup automatically performs failover during disruptions. Additionally, validate Multi-AZ support for other managed services, such as Amazon ElastiCache and Amazon DynamoDB. Use the Amazon RDS Multi-AZ documentation for more information.
  5. Implement replication across Availability Zones: Configure data replication mechanisms that span AZs for critical datasets. For example, enable S3 cross-region replication or use the replication features provided by databases like Amazon DynamoDB Global Tables and Amazon Aurora. Reference the Amazon S3 Replication documentation.
  6. Validate failover and recovery processes: Conduct periodic failover testing to ensure seamless transitions during AZ outages. Validate that your Auto Scaling Groups, Multi-AZ services, and data replication mechanisms work as intended under simulated failure scenarios. Review AWS Well-Architected Framework guidelines for best practices.
  7. Monitor AZ health and implement alerts: Use AWS CloudWatch to monitor the performance and health of resources across AZs. Create alarms to detect anomalies or failures early, and set up SNS notifications to ensure real-time alerts for critical events. Refer to the Amazon CloudWatch documentation for guidance.
  8. Optimize cost and compliance considerations: Ensure your workload is distributed efficiently to avoid unnecessary costs while adhering to regional compliance requirements. Use AWS Cost Explorer and AWS Config to maintain visibility into cost and security configurations. Refer to the AWS Cost Explorer documentation.

References

  • AWS Availability Zones in EC2
  • AWS Global Infrastructure and Availability Zones
  • AWS VPC User Guide
  • Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling
  • Amazon RDS Multi-AZ
  • Amazon S3 Replication
  • AWS Well-Architected Framework
  • Amazon CloudWatch
  • AWS Cost Explorer

countermeasure.name: Harden per-Availability Zone network segmentation
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps to implement the security countermeasure for AWS Availability Zones effectively:

  1. Design the Subnet Architecture:
    • Create distinct public and private subnets in each Availability Zone within your VPC.
    • Ensure public subnets are used for resources requiring internet access, such as load balancers.
    • Place resources such as application servers or databases in private subnets to prevent direct internet exposure.
  2. Configure Security Groups:
    • Apply the principle of least privilege when creating and configuring security groups. Ensure they allow only explicitly required traffic.
    • Examples: Restrict access to application servers to specific IP ranges or allow database ports only from application servers.
    • Allocate separate security groups for different resource tiers (e.g., web, application, database).
  3. Set Up Network Access Control Lists (NACLs):
    • Create NACLs for subnets to define fine-grained network-level policies for inbound and outbound traffic.
    • Implement deny rules for traffic that must explicitly be blocked, alongside allowing necessary traffic.
    • Regularly review NACL rules to optimize security settings.
  4. Create Dedicated Route Tables:
    • Assign dedicated route tables for each subnet tier to ensure isolation and control over routing.
    • Public subnets route tables should include routes to an internet gateway (IGW), allowing internet-based communication.
    • Private subnets should have routes directing traffic through a NAT gateway or VPC endpoint, without routing traffic to the IGW.
  5. Leverage VPC Endpoints:
    • Use VPC endpoints to privately access AWS services such as S3, DynamoDB, or Systems Manager without the need for public internet access.
    • Subnet traffic directed to VPC endpoints will stay entirely within the AWS network, improving security.
    • Ensure proper IAM policies on the VPC endpoints to enforce access controls for the associated AWS service.
  6. Regularly Review Routes:
    • Inspect route tables periodically to identify any unintended routes that may expose resources to unauthorized access or create conflicts.
    • Remove unnecessary routes and test changes thoroughly before deployment.
    • Monitor changes in route tables using AWS Config to ensure compliance with your network security policies.

For further details and best practices, consult the following references:

  • VPC Security Best Practices
  • AWS Infrastructure Security Basics

countermeasure.name: Implement Availability Zone-scoped logging and monitoring
countermeasure.desc:
Step-by-Step Guidance for Implementing the Security Countermeasure:

1. Enable VPC Flow Logs for Each Subnet

VPC Flow Logs provide visibility into the IP traffic handled by your VPC. By enabling flow logs at the subnet level, you gain granular insights into traffic patterns and potential issues.

  • Log into the AWS Management Console.
  • Navigate to the VPC section of the console.
  • Select the target VPC and then locate the specific subnets within it.
  • Click on the subnet you want to enable logs for and choose Create Flow Log.
  • Specify the destination for the logs (e.g., CloudWatch Logs or an Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Choose appropriate filters (e.g., All, Accept, Reject).
  • Save your settings and repeat for all relevant subnets.

2. Enable AWS CloudTrail Across All Regions

AWS CloudTrail provides event history and auditing capabilities for actions occurring within your AWS account. You should ensure CloudTrail is globally enabled and centralized for all regions.

  • Navigate to the CloudTrail console.
  • Click Create trail.
  • Provide a name for your trail and enable logging across All Regions.
  • Specify where logs should be stored (e.g., an Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Configure optional encryption and permission settings for enhanced security.
  • Validate the trail creation and ensure monitoring is enabled for Availability Zone activity.

3. Centralize Logs in Amazon CloudWatch Metrics/Alarms

To gain insights into anomalous traffic behavior and monitor configuration drift, integrate logs with CloudWatch and set up metrics and alarms with dimensions for Availability Zones.

  • Navigate to the CloudWatch console.
  • Ensure you have enabled log ingestion from VPC Flow Logs and AWS CloudTrail.
  • Inside the console, create Log Groups to centralize logs related to traffic patterns in specific Availability Zones.
  • Define Metric Filters to extract key metrics from logs, such as large spikes in denied traffic or unexpected changes.
  • Create alarms using CloudWatch thresholds to alert when unusual behavior is identified.
  • Test alarms and validate their alignment with Availability Zone identifiers.

4. Continuously Monitor for Configuration Drift

Configuration drift occurs when the infrastructure gradually diverges from its intended state. Detect and mitigate it using AWS Config and automated corrective actions.

  • Enable AWS Config to monitor resource configurations across your account.
  • Use Config rules to track compliance with security best practices, focusing on VPC security, flow logs, and trail settings.
  • Create custom Config rules to log and alert for changes in subnet configurations or flow log status.
  • Integrate relevant insights into CloudWatch dashboards for centralized visibility.

5. Detect Anomalous Traffic Patterns

Leverage specific AWS tools to detect unusual or harmful traffic patterns across Availability Zones.

  • Integrate Amazon GuardDuty to analyze flow logs and CloudTrail events for threats.
  • Enable DNS threat detection and monitor unusual spikes or requests within Availability Zones.
  • Regularly audit metric alarms and identify high-traffic periods that dont correlate with expected behavior.
  • Implement runtime protection tools to respond to live traffic anomalies.

References

  • VPC Security Best Practices
  • AWS Infrastructure Security Basics
  • VPC Flow Logs User Guide
  • CloudTrail Console User Guide
  • Amazon CloudWatch Logs Monitoring
  • What Is AWS Config?
  • What is Amazon GuardDuty?

countermeasure.name: Restrict inter-Availability Zone connectivity with least privilege
countermeasure.desc:
To improve the security of AWS Availability Zone implementations, follow these comprehensive steps:

  1. Scope Security Group Rules to Necessary Ports and Sources:

    • Decide which ports are required based on the specific functionality of the application or workloads hosted within the Availability Zone.
    • Restrict inbound and outbound traffic to only the ranges of IPs or VPC resources that require access.
    • For each security group, use precise CIDR ranges or specific AWS resources (i.e., other security groups or instance IDs) to define allowed traffic. Ensure the rules comply with the principle of least privilege.
    • Review the configurations frequently to ensure that only necessary access is permitted and to detect any unused or overly permissive rules.
    • To implement, navigate to the Security Groups section in your AWS Management Console or use the AWS CLI/SDK.

  2. Segment Tiers per Availability Zone:

    • Design your application tiers (e.g., web, app, and database tiers) to align with specific Availability Zones. This provides a natural layer of segmentation for additional security.
    • Configure security group rules to ensure that lateral movement is restricted between tiers, except for explicitly required communication flows. For example, only allow the application tier to communicate with the database tier.
    • Use subnet segmentation within Availability Zones to isolate traffic dynamically based on the application tier's role. Each tier can be assigned its own subnet with distinct configurations.

  3. Use ALB/NLB Target Groups with Controlled Registration Across Zones:

    • Configure Target Groups in your Application Load Balancer (ALB) or Network Load Balancer (NLB) to register instances based on specific Availability Zones.
    • Verify that health checks are configured properly to ensure that only healthy instances are registered in Target Groups.
    • Control registration by tagging or labeling instances according to their purpose and zone, and create IAM policies or scripts for automated instance registration based on exclusion or inclusion criteria.
    • Use listener rules in your ALB or NLB to enforce zone-specific routing if necessary.

  4. Review NACLs to Minimize Lateral Movement:

    • For each subnet in your VPC, review Network Access Control List (NACL) rules to ensure that only legitimate traffic flows are allowed.
    • Block unnecessary intra-zone traffic by explicitly denying overly permissive rules, especially those allowing access between subnets of different tiers unnecessarily.
    • Use deny rules explicitly where feasible to block traffic that should not have lateral access across subnets and Availability Zones.
    • Regularly audit NACL rules using AWS Config to ensure compliance with best practices and monitor for drift or outdated configurations.

References

  • VPC Security Best Practices
  • Amazon EC2 Security Groups
  • What Is an Application Load Balancer?
  • Network Load Balancer Overview
  • Network ACL Overview
  • AWS Config Evaluation of Rules

countermeasure.name: Use stable Availability Zone ids and avoid hardcoded names
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure resources in AWS are distributed across distinct physical zones and maintain high availability, adhere to the following steps:

  1. Understand AWS Availability Zone IDs:
    • Availability Zones are distinct from "names" such as us-east-1a. These names vary per account due to internal mapping, but Availability Zone IDs (e.g., use-az1) remain consistent across accounts.
    • Refer to the AWS documentation on Availability Zone IDs to familiarize yourself with this concept: Availability Zone Concepts.
  2. Use Programmatic Discovery via the AWS CLI or SDK to dynamically retrieve Availability Zone information:
    • Run the following AWS CLI command to list all Availability Zones within a region:aws ec2 describe-availability-zones --region REGION_NAMEReplace REGION_NAME with your selected region (e.g., us-east-1).
    • In the output, reference the ZoneId fields (e.g., use-az1). These IDs can be used reliably to distribute resources across distinct physical locations.
  3. Automate Resource Spreading Across Zones:
    • Design your infrastructure to programmatically spread workloads across the unique ZoneId values using orchestration tools such as AWS CloudFormation, AWS SDK (for Python boto3 or Java SDK), or APIs.
    • Create deployment logic to verify that the resources are evenly distributed by cross-checking the ZoneId mappings during deployment or updates.
  4. Document the ZoneId mappings:
    • Maintain a record of Availability Zone IDs and their associated resources for each deployment or major change.
    • Store this documentation securely in a versioned repository or centralized configuration management system, such as AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store or an internal inventory system.
  5. Continuously Audit Resource Placement:
    • Periodically run the DescribeAvailabilityZones API or CLI command and validate the resource placement against the mapping records for consistency.
    • Update deployment documentation promptly if new zones are added or existing ones are modified.

References

  • Availability Zone Concepts
