countermeasure.name: Protect routers by controlling access lists for remote administration
countermeasure.desc:
Configure Access Control Lists (ACLs) to restrict access to remote management interfaces on the router, ensuring that only authorized users can access sensitive configuration settings. By defining ACLs that specify IP addresses, user roles, or security groups, you can control which devices or users are allowed to connect to management interfaces such as SSH, HTTP, or HTTPS. This minimizes the risk of unauthorized access or remote exploitation, securing the router's management capabilities and preventing malicious actors from altering configurations.

Implementation Steps:

Define ACLs for Remote Management Access:

  • Identify the IP addresses or IP ranges of authorized devices and configure ACLs to only allow these addresses to access management interfaces.
  • Block access from any unauthorized or unknown sources to prevent remote login attempts from external networks.

Use Strong Authentication for Remote Management:

  • Require multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all remote management connections where possible.
  • Ensure the use of strong, unique passwords or keys for access to remote management interfaces.

Limit Management Protocols:

  • Disable unnecessary remote management protocols (e.g., Telnet) and ensure that secure protocols like SSH and HTTPS are the only ones enabled.
  • Restrict remote access to specific ports required for management, minimizing potential attack vectors.

Monitor and Audit Remote Access Logs:

  • Regularly review logs of remote management access to detect unauthorized attempts and potential security breaches.
  • Set up alerts to notify administrators of suspicious login activities or failed access attempts.

Test ACL Configurations:

  • Periodically test ACL configurations to verify that only authorized users can access remote management interfaces and ensure no unintentional access is allowed.

References:

  • Cisco ACL Configuration Guide

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1021 - Restrict Web-Based Content

countermeasure.name: Setup a strong combination of credentials
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all passwords for accessing the router are strong, complex, and regularly updated to reduce the risk of unauthorized access. Strong passwords should include a combination of upper and lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters. Avoid using default or easily guessable passwords. Implement a password management policy that mandates regular password changes and prevents reuse of old passwords. This practice helps to mitigate the risk of password-based attacks, such as brute force or dictionary attacks, by making it more difficult for malicious actors to gain unauthorized access to the router.

Implementation Steps:

Define Strong Password Requirements:

  • Require passwords to be at least 12-16 characters long and contain a mix of uppercase, lowercase, numbers, and special characters.
  • Prohibit the use of common passwords, easily guessable information, or default credentials.

Enforce Regular Password Changes:

  • Implement a policy that requires passwords to be updated every 60-90 days.
  • Prevent users from reusing old passwords to ensure that passwords are unique and regularly refreshed.

Use Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):

  • When possible, enable MFA for accessing the routers management interface to add an additional layer of security beyond just passwords.

Monitor Password Access Logs:

  • Regularly review logs to detect any suspicious attempts to access the router with invalid or outdated passwords.
  • Set up alerts for failed login attempts to notify administrators of potential attacks.

Educate Users on Password Security:

  • Provide training to administrators and users on creating secure passwords and the importance of regularly updating them.
  • Promote the use of password managers to securely store and manage complex passwords.

References:

  • National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Password Guidelines

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers try to take advantage of a wide attack surface
threat.desc:
General Threat Description: 

Attackers exploiting a wide attack surface attempt to leverage multiple potential entry points or vulnerabilities within a routers configuration, software, or hardware. A wide attack surface increases the risk of successful exploitation due to the larger number of access points for malicious actors.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External Attackers: Malicious actors attempting to exploit unpatched vulnerabilities, open ports, or weak configurations.
  • Internal Attackers: Users or devices with access to the network who may exploit internal entry points.
  • Automated Tools: Attackers using scripts or bots to scan for open vulnerabilities.

Impacts:

  • Increased likelihood of a breach due to multiple vulnerabilities.
  • Compromise of the router or network control.
  • Loss of data integrity and availability.
  • Potential for widespread network disruptions or system compromises.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker scans a router with many open ports and unpatched vulnerabilities, exploiting one to gain control.
  • A misconfigured router with various exposed services allows an attacker to access and manipulate sensitive network settings.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1060 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder

threat.name: Dictionary-based or brute force password attack
threat.desc:
General Threat Description: 

A dictionary-based or brute force password attack involves an attacker systematically attempting to guess passwords by either using a list of common passwords (dictionary attack) or trying every possible combination of characters (brute force attack). This type of attack targets routers with weak or default passwords that can be easily cracked.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External Attackers: Malicious actors attempting to gain unauthorized access by guessing router passwords.
  • Internal Attackers: Insiders using brute force techniques to access sensitive areas within the network.
  • Automated Tools: Attackers use software that rapidly tests large numbers of passwords.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to router settings, configurations, and network resources.
  • Potential for network control compromise or configuration manipulation.
  • Data theft, system compromise, or network disruptions.
  • Escalation of privileges, leading to broader network vulnerabilities.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker uses a brute force tool to guess a weak router password and gains administrative control, altering network configurations.
  • An attacker launches a dictionary attack on a router using common passwords, successfully accessing the device and exfiltrating sensitive information.

threat.name: Accessing functionality not properly constrained by ACLs
threat.desc:
General Threat Description: 

Improperly configured ACLs on a router can allow unauthorized users or devices to access restricted functionalities, potentially leading to security breaches.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Internal Attackers: Users or devices with network access but insufficient privileges.
  • External Attackers: Unauthorized users exploiting router vulnerabilities.
  • Automated Tools: Scanners targeting misconfigured routers.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive functions.
  • Data breaches or system control compromises.
  • Denial of service or network disruptions.
  • Privilege escalation.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker exploits weak ACL settings to access the routers admin interface and alter network configurations.
  • An insider gains unauthorized access to sensitive data via a misconfigured ACL.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-15
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-15: External Control of System or Configuration Setting One or more system settings or configuration elements can be externally controlled by a user. Allowing external control of system settings can disrupt service or cause an application to behave in unexpected, and potentially malicious ways.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-300
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-300: Channel Accessible by Non-Endpoint The product does not adequately verify the identity of actors at both ends of a communication channel, or does not adequately ensure the integrity of the channel, in a way that allows the channel to be accessed or influenced by an actor that is not an endpoint. In order to establish secure communication between two parties, it is often important to adequately verify the identity of entities at each end of the communication channel. Inadequate or inconsistent verification may result in insufficient or incorrect identification of either communicating entity. This can have negative consequences such as misplaced trust in the entity at the other end of the channel. An attacker can leverage this by interposing between the communicating entities and masquerading as the original entity. In the absence of sufficient verification of identity, such an attacker can eavesdrop and potentially modify the communication between the original entities.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-540
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-540: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users. There are situations where it is critical to remove source code from an area or server. For example, obtaining Perl source code on a system allows an attacker to understand the logic of the script and extract extremely useful information such as code bugs or logins and passwords.

weakness.name: CWE-942
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-942: Permissive Cross-domain Policy with Untrusted Domains The product uses a cross-domain policy file that includes domains that should not be trusted.

countermeasure.name: Automate secure configuration management
countermeasure.desc:
Eliminate manual errors and detect drift by managing every Direct Connect objectconnections, LAGs, virtual interfaces, gateway associationsthrough vetted infrastructure-as-code (IaC) pipelines and continuous compliance checks:

  1. define configurations in IaC
    • Use AWS CloudFormation, Terraform, or AWS CDK modules that encapsulate approved settings (BGP ASN ranges, VLAN IDs, Jumbo Frames, SiteLink = false).
    • Parameterize only what needs to vary (Region, speed); hard-code security defaults (e.g., enableSiteLink: false, mtu: 9001).
  2. enforce change control
    • Protect the IaC repo with branch protection, mandatory code-review, and automated security linting (cfn-nag, tfsec).
    • Require all Direct Connect changes to flow through the pipeline; block console or ad-hoc CLI edits with an Organizations SCP denying directconnect:* when aws:CalledViaLast cloudformation.amazonaws.com or your CI role.
  3. continuous drift detection
    • Turn on AWS Config rule directconnect-connection-config-check (custom) that compares live attributes to the IaC source of truth; mark resources NON_COMPLIANT on mismatch.
    • Trigger an EventBridge rule that opens a ticket or auto-reverts drift via an SSM automation document.
  4. version and audit
    • Tag every Direct Connect resource with the Git commit hash that provisioned it (IaCCommit=<sha>).
    • Store pipeline logs and change sets in an immutable S3 bucket for forensic review.

Automated, declarative management guarantees consistent security baselines, accelerates approved changes, and surfaces unauthorized modifications within minutes.

countermeasure.name: Enforce IAM identity-based policies for AWS Direct Connect
countermeasure.desc:
Create narrowly scoped IAM policies (and, if you use AWS Organizations, complementary SCPs) so that only approved network-admin roles can perform Direct Connect management actionssuch as CreateConnection, AllocateHostedConnection, ConfirmPrivateVirtualInterface, or DeleteLag.

  • Author purpose-built roles give each network-engineering or automation role a custom policy that allows only the Direct Connect APIs it truly needs and only in approved Regions or on resources tagged Environment=prod. Example snippet:
  • {
     "Effect": "Allow",
     "Action": [
       "directconnect:CreateConnection",
       "directconnect:DeleteConnection",
       "directconnect:Describe*"
     ],
     "Resource": "*",
     "Condition": {
       "StringEquals": { "aws:RequestedRegion": [ "us-east-1", "eu-west-1" ] },
       "ForAllValues:StringEquals": { "aws:ResourceTag/NetworkOwner": "net-ops" }
     }
    }
  • Block everyone else attach an SCP that denies directconnect:* unless the principal ARN matches the network-admin roles or the AWS SSO group you designate.
  • Require MFA for sensitive calls add an IAM condition BoolIfExists/aws:MultiFactorAuthPresent : true so console users must present MFA when modifying connections or virtual interfaces.
  • Monitor and audit stream CloudTrail events that match directconnect:* to CloudWatch Logs and set an EventBridge rule to alert on any caller outside your allow-list.
  • Review quarterly export IAM Access Analyzer last used data and remove unused Direct Connect permissions; update Region and tag conditions as your footprint changes.

Enforcing identity-based, least-privilege policies prevents unauthorized creation, deletion, or tampering of Direct Connect links that could disrupt hybrid connectivity.

References

countermeasure.name: Implement BGP hijacking protections
countermeasure.desc:
Protect Direct Connect virtual interfaces from BGP hijacking and route leaks by configuring both ends of the peering sessionyour on-prem router and AWSto accept only authenticated, pre-agreed prefixes and AS paths:

  1. enable BGP MD5 authentication
    • When you create or update the private or transit virtual interface, specify a BGP MD5 key (Amazon console Add BGP password).
    • Configure the matching password <secret> on your customer router so unauthenticated sessions are rejected.
  2. advertise and accept explicit prefix lists
    • On your router, use a prefix-list / route-map that only advertises the exact CIDR blocks you own (no more-specifics, no 0.0.0.0/0).
    • Apply an inbound filter that accepts only the AWS-announced RFC 1918 ranges (or any public space you expect) to prevent a poisoned route table.
  3. set max-prefix & as-path filters
    • neighbor <aws-peering-ip> maximum-prefix <N> restart 5pick N slightly above the number of prefixes you legitimately expect (e.g., 5 % head-room).
    • Deny inbound prefixes whose AS_PATH is not exactly AS16509 (AWS) or the sequence you anticipate for a hosted connection.
  4. enable BFD and low hold timers
    • Turn on Bidirectional Forwarding Detection (BFD) and set aggressive timers (e.g., 300 ms, 3 multiplier) so hijacked or flapping sessions drop quickly.
    • If your device lacks BFD, reduce BGP keep-alive/hold timers (30 / 90 s) instead of the defaults.
  5. monitor and alert
    • Stream Direct Connect BGP state change and RouteChange CloudWatch metrics; alarm on BGPPeerDown, MaxPrefixesExceeded, or unexpected ASN/path events.
    • Log all BGP syslog messages on the customer router to a SIEM and detect new or more-specific routes instantly.
  6. review quarterly
    • Compare advertised prefixes against your IPAM source of truth; prune any stale routes.
    • Rotate the BGP MD5 key when staff leave or devices are replaced.

These layered controlsauthentication, strict prefix/as-path filtering, and rapid failure detectiongreatly reduce the chance that an attacker can hijack your Direct Connect traffic or inject malicious routes.

References

  • AWS Direct Connect routing policies and BGP communities

countermeasure.name: Monitor and safeguard BGP routes
countermeasure.desc:
Continuously watch every Direct Connect BGP session and automatically flagor shut downany route change that could steer traffic to an unexpected destination.

  1. Stream BGP telemetry to CloudWatch
    • Enable the Direct Connect metrics BgpPeerState, BgpRouteFlapDampening, and BGPMaxPrefixesExceeded.
    • Create CloudWatch alarms that fire when a peer drops (BgpPeerState = 3), the route count jumps beyond the configured max-prefix value, or flapping exceeds a defined threshold.
  2. Log all route advertisements
    • On the customer router, export BGP UPDATE messages to a syslog or NetFlow collector; forward to your SIEM for real-time correlation.
    • Retain logs for at least 90 days so you can trace when and how a suspicious prefix entered the table.
  3. Detect drift with AWS Config & EventBridge
    • Deploy a custom AWS Config rule that compares the live list of accepted/advertised prefixes against your approved prefix list in IPAM.
    • When Config marks a resource NON_COMPLIANT, trigger an EventBridge rule that pages on-call staff andoptionallyruns an SSM Automation document to disable the virtual interface until reviewed.
  4. Implement route sanity checks
    • Use the routers prefix-list + route-map to drop any prefix longer than /24 or outside your owned CIDR blocks.
    • Set neighbor <peer-ip> maximum-prefix <N> restart 5 to halt a session that suddenly advertises too many routes.
  5. Visualise and review
    • Build a CloudWatch dashboard that shows current prefix count, peer state, and alarm status for every virtual interface.
    • Review logs and metrics weekly; investigate any new ASN in the AS-PATH or unexplained rise in prefix count.

Proactive monitoring combined with automatic drift detection stops hijacked, leaked, or mis-typed routes before they impact production traffic.

References

  • Monitoring Direct Connect BGP sessions with CloudWatch metrics
  • AWS Direct Connect routing policies and BGP communities

countermeasure.name: Regularly audit Direct Connect configurations
countermeasure.desc:
At least once per quarterand after every network changegenerate and review a complete inventory of Direct Connect resources (connections, LAGs, virtual interfaces, gateway associations, route filters, and BGP settings). Compare the live state against your infrastructure-as-code definitions and security baseline, then remediate drift immediately.

Implementation guidance

  1. Automate the snapshot
    • Run aws directconnect describe-* commands (or Terraform / CloudFormation drift-detect) from a scheduled pipeline; export JSON to an S3 bucket versioned for audit.
  2. Evaluate with AWS Config & Security Hub
    • Enable custom and managed Config rulesfor example, flag connections without BGP MD5 keys or VIFs without route filters. Send findings to Security Hub so they appear on your compliance dashboard.
  3. Cross-check critical attributes
    • Verify port speed, LOA expiry, VLAN IDs, SiteLink status, BGP ASN, maximum-prefix limits, and MD5 keys against your approved standards document or IPAM system.
  4. Document and remediate
    • Publish an audit report listing compliant items, drift, and required fixes. Track remediation tasks in your ticket system and confirm closure before the next audit cycle.

Regular, tool-driven audits prevent silent mis-configurations that could break redundancy, expose routes, or violate compliance requirements.

References

  • Evaluating Resources with AWS Config Rules

countermeasure.name: Use PFS-supported cipher suites
countermeasure.desc:
Whether youre calling the AWS APIs that manage Direct Connect or encrypting application payloads that traverse the circuit (for example, TLS to private NLBs or HTTPS to AWS service endpoints), configure the TLS stack so it negotiates only cipher suites that provide Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS)that is, suites that use an ephemeral Diffie-Hellman key exchange such as ECDHE or DHE.

Implementation guidance

  1. restrict the client cipher list
    • On routers, firewalls, and application servers that initiate TLS sessions over Direct Connect, remove all static-key suites (RSA key exchange) and legacy ciphers (3DES, RC4).
    • Keep the list to modern suites such as TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256, TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384, or (preferably) TLS 1.3 defaults.
  2. enforce on inbound endpoints
    • For load balancers and APIs hosted in AWS, select an ELB security policy that requires TLS 1.2/1.3 with PFS (for example ELBSecurityPolicy-TLS13-1-2-Res-2021-06).
    • Reject client hellos that offer only non-PFS suites.
  3. verify with automated scans
    • Use openssl s_client -cipher 'aNULL' -connect host:443 and expect no handshake.
    • Schedule weekly or monthly scans (SSLLabs, AWS Inspector network assessments) to confirm no regressions.
  4. monitor for legacy fall-back
    • Enable CloudTrail data-events for ELB and look for TLSNegotiationError.
    • Set CloudWatch alarms on a spike in cipher-mismatch metricsan early sign that a client or server reverted to weak crypto.

PFS ensures that, even if a long-term private key is later compromised, past TLS sessions cannot be decryptedan essential property for protecting high-value traffic flowing over dedicated circuits like AWS Direct Connect.

References

  • Create an HTTPS listener for your Application Load Balancer

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data interception
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data interception involves unauthorized parties gaining access to data as it is being transmitted over the network. This threat compromises the confidentiality and integrity of data sent via AWS Direct Connect, potentially leading to data breaches and unauthorized access to sensitive information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, malicious insiders, and state-sponsored actors. Attack vectors include man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks, compromised network devices, and physical tapping of communication lines.

Impacts

Data interception can result in confidentiality breaches, data integrity compromise, operational disruption, reputational damage, and financial loss.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker intercepts communication between an on-premises network and AWS by positioning themselves between the endpoints, allowing them to eavesdrop or inject malicious data into the communication stream.

threat.name: Unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access refers to individuals gaining access to AWS Direct Connect resources without proper authorization. This can occur due to weak access controls, compromised credentials, or configuration errors, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized manipulation of resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, malicious insiders, and attackers exploiting compromised credentials. Attack vectors include stolen or weak passwords, misconfigured IAM policies, and exploitation of insufficiently restricted network access.

Impacts

Unauthorized access can result in data breaches, loss of sensitive information, unauthorized changes to configurations, financial loss, and reputational damage. It compromises the integrity and confidentiality of the AWS environment.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker gains access to AWS Direct Connect resources by exploiting weak or stolen credentials, allowing them to view or manipulate sensitive data. Another scenario involves a misconfigured IAM policy that inadvertently grants excessive permissions to a user, leading to unauthorized actions within the AWS environment.

threat.name: Insecure configuration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insecure configuration involves improper setup of AWS Direct Connect resources, leading to potential vulnerabilities. Misconfigurations can result from errors in security settings, inadequate access controls, or failure to follow best practices, exposing the infrastructure to various threats.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include system administrators, attackers exploiting configuration errors, and automated tools scanning for vulnerabilities. Attack vectors include misconfigured access controls, incorrect security group settings, and failure to apply updates or patches.

Impacts

Insecure configurations can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, service disruptions, and potential exploitation of vulnerable systems. These issues can compromise the security and integrity of data and services.

Example Attack Scenarios

An administrator mistakenly configures overly permissive access controls, allowing unauthorized users to access sensitive data through AWS Direct Connect. Another scenario involves outdated security settings that an attacker exploits to gain unauthorized access, leading to data breaches and service disruptions.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: BGP hijacking
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

BGP hijacking involves malicious actors rerouting internet traffic by corrupting the Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) routing tables. This allows attackers to intercept, monitor, or manipulate data intended for legitimate network paths, potentially impacting AWS Direct Connect's communication routes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, state-sponsored actors, and rogue network operators. Attack vectors involve manipulating BGP announcements to falsely advertise ownership of IP prefixes, causing traffic to be misrouted through the attackers network.

Impacts

BGP hijacking can lead to data interception, traffic analysis, disruption of services, loss of data integrity, and potential data breaches. It can cause significant operational disruptions and loss of trust in network security.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker corrupts BGP routing tables to divert traffic from a corporate network to their own servers, allowing them to capture sensitive information transmitted via AWS Direct Connect. Another scenario involves an attacker using a compromised or rogue router to announce false BGP routes, disrupting service availability and causing a loss of connectivity for critical applications.

weakness.name: CWE-15
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-15: External Control of System or Configuration Setting One or more system settings or configuration elements can be externally controlled by a user. Allowing external control of system settings can disrupt service or cause an application to behave in unexpected, and potentially malicious ways.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-300
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-300: Channel Accessible by Non-Endpoint The product does not adequately verify the identity of actors at both ends of a communication channel, or does not adequately ensure the integrity of the channel, in a way that allows the channel to be accessed or influenced by an actor that is not an endpoint. In order to establish secure communication between two parties, it is often important to adequately verify the identity of entities at each end of the communication channel. Inadequate or inconsistent verification may result in insufficient or incorrect identification of either communicating entity. This can have negative consequences such as misplaced trust in the entity at the other end of the channel. An attacker can leverage this by interposing between the communicating entities and masquerading as the original entity. In the absence of sufficient verification of identity, such an attacker can eavesdrop and potentially modify the communication between the original entities.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-540
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-540: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users. There are situations where it is critical to remove source code from an area or server. For example, obtaining Perl source code on a system allows an attacker to understand the logic of the script and extract extremely useful information such as code bugs or logins and passwords.

weakness.name: CWE-942
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-942: Permissive Cross-domain Policy with Untrusted Domains The product uses a cross-domain policy file that includes domains that should not be trusted.

countermeasure.name: Automate secure configuration management
countermeasure.desc:
Eliminate manual errors and detect drift by managing every Direct Connect objectconnections, LAGs, virtual interfaces, gateway associationsthrough vetted infrastructure-as-code (IaC) pipelines and continuous compliance checks:

  1. define configurations in IaC
    • Use AWS CloudFormation, Terraform, or AWS CDK modules that encapsulate approved settings (BGP ASN ranges, VLAN IDs, Jumbo Frames, SiteLink = false).
    • Parameterize only what needs to vary (Region, speed); hard-code security defaults (e.g., enableSiteLink: false, mtu: 9001).
  2. enforce change control
    • Protect the IaC repo with branch protection, mandatory code-review, and automated security linting (cfn-nag, tfsec).
    • Require all Direct Connect changes to flow through the pipeline; block console or ad-hoc CLI edits with an Organizations SCP denying directconnect:* when aws:CalledViaLast cloudformation.amazonaws.com or your CI role.
  3. continuous drift detection
    • Turn on AWS Config rule directconnect-connection-config-check (custom) that compares live attributes to the IaC source of truth; mark resources NON_COMPLIANT on mismatch.
    • Trigger an EventBridge rule that opens a ticket or auto-reverts drift via an SSM automation document.
  4. version and audit
    • Tag every Direct Connect resource with the Git commit hash that provisioned it (IaCCommit=<sha>).
    • Store pipeline logs and change sets in an immutable S3 bucket for forensic review.

Automated, declarative management guarantees consistent security baselines, accelerates approved changes, and surfaces unauthorized modifications within minutes.

References

  • What is AWS Direct Connect?
  • What Is AWS Config?

countermeasure.desc:
At least once per quarterand after every network changegenerate and review a complete inventory of Direct Connect resources (connections, LAGs, virtual interfaces, gateway associations, route filters, and BGP settings). Compare the live state against your infrastructure-as-code definitions and security baseline, then remediate drift immediately.

Implementation guidance

  1. Automate the snapshot
    • Run aws directconnect describe-* commands (or Terraform / CloudFormation drift-detect) from a scheduled pipeline; export JSON to an S3 bucket versioned for audit.
  2. Evaluate with AWS Config & Security Hub
    • Enable custom and managed Config rulesfor example, flag connections without BGP MD5 keys or VIFs without route filters. Send findings to Security Hub so they appear on your compliance dashboard.
  3. Cross-check critical attributes
    • Verify port speed, LOA expiry, VLAN IDs, SiteLink status, BGP ASN, maximum-prefix limits, and MD5 keys against your approved standards document or IPAM system.
  4. Document and remediate
    • Publish an audit report listing compliant items, drift, and required fixes. Track remediation tasks in your ticket system and confirm closure before the next audit cycle.

Regular, tool-driven audits prevent silent mis-configurations that could break redundancy, expose routes, or violate compliance requirements.

References

  • Evaluating Resources with AWS Config Rules

countermeasure.name: Use PFS-supported cipher suites
countermeasure.desc:
Whether youre calling the AWS APIs that manage Direct Connect or encrypting application payloads that traverse the circuit (for example, TLS to private NLBs or HTTPS to AWS service endpoints), configure the TLS stack so it negotiates only cipher suites that provide Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS)that is, suites that use an ephemeral Diffie-Hellman key exchange such as ECDHE or DHE.

Implementation guidance

  1. restrict the client cipher list
    • On routers, firewalls, and application servers that initiate TLS sessions over Direct Connect, remove all static-key suites (RSA key exchange) and legacy ciphers (3DES, RC4).
    • Keep the list to modern suites such as TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256, TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384, or (preferably) TLS 1.3 defaults.
  2. enforce on inbound endpoints
    • For load balancers and APIs hosted in AWS, select an ELB security policy that requires TLS 1.2/1.3 with PFS (for example ELBSecurityPolicy-TLS13-1-2-Res-2021-06).
    • Reject client hellos that offer only non-PFS suites.
  3. verify with automated scans
    • Use openssl s_client -cipher 'aNULL' -connect host:443 and expect no handshake.
    • Schedule weekly or monthly scans (SSLLabs, AWS Inspector network assessments) to confirm no regressions.
  4. monitor for legacy fall-back
    • Enable CloudTrail data-events for ELB and look for TLSNegotiationError.
    • Set CloudWatch alarms on a spike in cipher-mismatch metricsan early sign that a client or server reverted to weak crypto.

PFS ensures that, even if a long-term private key is later compromised, past TLS sessions cannot be decryptedan essential property for protecting high-value traffic flowing over dedicated circuits like AWS Direct Connect.

References

  • Create an HTTPS listener for your Application Load Balancer

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data interception
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data interception involves unauthorized parties gaining access to data as it is being transmitted over the network. This threat compromises the confidentiality and integrity of data sent via AWS Direct Connect, potentially leading to data breaches and unauthorized access to sensitive information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, malicious insiders, and state-sponsored actors. Attack vectors include man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks, compromised network devices, and physical tapping of communication lines.

Impacts

Data interception can result in confidentiality breaches, data integrity compromise, operational disruption, reputational damage, and financial loss.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker intercepts communication between an on-premises network and AWS by positioning themselves between the endpoints, allowing them to eavesdrop or inject malicious data into the communication stream.

threat.name: Unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access refers to individuals gaining access to AWS Direct Connect resources without proper authorization. This can occur due to weak access controls, compromised credentials, or configuration errors, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized manipulation of resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, malicious insiders, and attackers exploiting compromised credentials. Attack vectors include stolen or weak passwords, misconfigured IAM policies, and exploitation of insufficiently restricted network access.

Impacts

Unauthorized access can result in data breaches, loss of sensitive information, unauthorized changes to configurations, financial loss, and reputational damage. It compromises the integrity and confidentiality of the AWS environment.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker gains access to AWS Direct Connect resources by exploiting weak or stolen credentials, allowing them to view or manipulate sensitive data. Another scenario involves a misconfigured IAM policy that inadvertently grants excessive permissions to a user, leading to unauthorized actions within the AWS environment.

threat.name: Insecure configuration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insecure configuration involves improper setup of AWS Direct Connect resources, leading to potential vulnerabilities. Misconfigurations can result from errors in security settings, inadequate access controls, or failure to follow best practices, exposing the infrastructure to various threats.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include system administrators, attackers exploiting configuration errors, and automated tools scanning for vulnerabilities. Attack vectors include misconfigured access controls, incorrect security group settings, and failure to apply updates or patches.

Impacts

Insecure configurations can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, service disruptions, and potential exploitation of vulnerable systems. These issues can compromise the security and integrity of data and services.

Example Attack Scenarios

An administrator mistakenly configures overly permissive access controls, allowing unauthorized users to access sensitive data through AWS Direct Connect. Another scenario involves outdated security settings that an attacker exploits to gain unauthorized access, leading to data breaches and service disruptions.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: BGP hijacking
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

BGP hijacking involves malicious actors rerouting internet traffic by corrupting the Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) routing tables. This allows attackers to intercept, monitor, or manipulate data intended for legitimate network paths, potentially impacting AWS Direct Connect's communication routes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, state-sponsored actors, and rogue network operators. Attack vectors involve manipulating BGP announcements to falsely advertise ownership of IP prefixes, causing traffic to be misrouted through the attackers network.

Impacts

BGP hijacking can lead to data interception, traffic analysis, disruption of services, loss of data integrity, and potential data breaches. It can cause significant operational disruptions and loss of trust in network security.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker corrupts BGP routing tables to divert traffic from a corporate network to their own servers, allowing them to capture sensitive information transmitted via AWS Direct Connect. Another scenario involves an attacker using a compromised or rogue router to announce false BGP routes, disrupting service availability and causing a loss of connectivity for critical applications.

component.name: Partner Cage
component.desc: Partner Cage within the Direct Connect location.

weakness.name: CWE-15
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-15: External Control of System or Configuration Setting One or more system settings or configuration elements can be externally controlled by a user. Allowing external control of system settings can disrupt service or cause an application to behave in unexpected, and potentially malicious ways.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-300
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-300: Channel Accessible by Non-Endpoint The product does not adequately verify the identity of actors at both ends of a communication channel, or does not adequately ensure the integrity of the channel, in a way that allows the channel to be accessed or influenced by an actor that is not an endpoint. In order to establish secure communication between two parties, it is often important to adequately verify the identity of entities at each end of the communication channel. Inadequate or inconsistent verification may result in insufficient or incorrect identification of either communicating entity. This can have negative consequences such as misplaced trust in the entity at the other end of the channel. An attacker can leverage this by interposing between the communicating entities and masquerading as the original entity. In the absence of sufficient verification of identity, such an attacker can eavesdrop and potentially modify the communication between the original entities.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-540
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-540: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users. There are situations where it is critical to remove source code from an area or server. For example, obtaining Perl source code on a system allows an attacker to understand the logic of the script and extract extremely useful information such as code bugs or logins and passwords.

weakness.name: CWE-942
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-942: Permissive Cross-domain Policy with Untrusted Domains The product uses a cross-domain policy file that includes domains that should not be trusted.

countermeasure.name: Automate secure configuration management
countermeasure.desc:
Eliminate manual errors and detect drift by managing every Direct Connect objectconnections, LAGs, virtual interfaces, gateway associationsthrough vetted infrastructure-as-code (IaC) pipelines and continuous compliance checks:

  1. define configurations in IaC
    • Use AWS CloudFormation, Terraform, or AWS CDK modules that encapsulate approved settings (BGP ASN ranges, VLAN IDs, Jumbo Frames, SiteLink = false).
    • Parameterize only what needs to vary (Region, speed); hard-code security defaults (e.g., enableSiteLink: false, mtu: 9001).
  2. enforce change control
    • Protect the IaC repo with branch protection, mandatory code-review, and automated security linting (cfn-nag, tfsec).
    • Require all Direct Connect changes to flow through the pipeline; block console or ad-hoc CLI edits with an Organizations SCP denying directconnect:* when aws:CalledViaLast cloudformation.amazonaws.com or your CI role.
  3. continuous drift detection
    • Turn on AWS Config rule directconnect-connection-config-check (custom) that compares live attributes to the IaC source of truth; mark resources NON_COMPLIANT on mismatch.
    • Trigger an EventBridge rule that opens a ticket or auto-reverts drift via an SSM automation document.
  4. version and audit
    • Tag every Direct Connect resource with the Git commit hash that provisioned it (IaCCommit=<sha>).
    • Store pipeline logs and change sets in an immutable S3 bucket for forensic review.

Automated, declarative management guarantees consistent security baselines, accelerates approved changes, and surfaces unauthorized modifications within minutes.

References

  • What is AWS Direct Connect?
  • What Is AWS Config?

reference.name: Security in AWS Direct Connect

countermeasure.name: Enforce IAM identity-based policies for AWS Direct Connect
countermeasure.desc:
Create narrowly scoped IAM policies (and, if you use AWS Organizations, complementary SCPs) so that only approved network-admin roles can perform Direct Connect management actionssuch as CreateConnection, AllocateHostedConnection, ConfirmPrivateVirtualInterface, or DeleteLag.

  • Author purpose-built roles give each network-engineering or automation role a custom policy that allows only the Direct Connect APIs it truly needs and only in approved Regions or on resources tagged Environment=prod. Example snippet:
  • {
     "Effect": "Allow",
     "Action": [
       "directconnect:CreateConnection",
       "directconnect:DeleteConnection",
       "directconnect:Describe*"
     ],
     "Resource": "*",
     "Condition": {
       "StringEquals": { "aws:RequestedRegion": [ "us-east-1", "eu-west-1" ] },
       "ForAllValues:StringEquals": { "aws:ResourceTag/NetworkOwner": "net-ops" }
     }
    }
  • Block everyone else attach an SCP that denies directconnect:* unless the principal ARN matches the network-admin roles or the AWS SSO group you designate.
  • Require MFA for sensitive calls add an IAM condition BoolIfExists/aws:MultiFactorAuthPresent : true so console users must present MFA when modifying connections or virtual interfaces.
  • Monitor and audit stream CloudTrail events that match directconnect:* to CloudWatch Logs and set an EventBridge rule to alert on any caller outside your allow-list.
  • Review quarterly export IAM Access Analyzer last used data and remove unused Direct Connect permissions; update Region and tag conditions as your footprint changes.

Enforcing identity-based, least-privilege policies prevents unauthorized creation, deletion, or tampering of Direct Connect links that could disrupt hybrid connectivity.

References

  • What is AWS Direct Connect?

countermeasure.name: Implement BGP hijacking protections
countermeasure.desc:
Protect Direct Connect virtual interfaces from BGP hijacking and route leaks by configuring both ends of the peering sessionyour on-prem router and AWSto accept only authenticated, pre-agreed prefixes and AS paths:

  1. enable BGP MD5 authentication
    • When you create or update the private or transit virtual interface, specify a BGP MD5 key (Amazon console Add BGP password).
    • Configure the matching password <secret> on your customer router so unauthenticated sessions are rejected.
  2. advertise and accept explicit prefix lists
    • On your router, use a prefix-list / route-map that only advertises the exact CIDR blocks you own (no more-specifics, no 0.0.0.0/0).
    • Apply an inbound filter that accepts only the AWS-announced RFC 1918 ranges (or any public space you expect) to prevent a poisoned route table.
  3. set max-prefix & as-path filters
    • neighbor <aws-peering-ip> maximum-prefix <N> restart 5pick N slightly above the number of prefixes you legitimately expect (e.g., 5 % head-room).
    • Deny inbound prefixes whose AS_PATH is not exactly AS16509 (AWS) or the sequence you anticipate for a hosted connection.
  4. enable BFD and low hold timers
    • Turn on Bidirectional Forwarding Detection (BFD) and set aggressive timers (e.g., 300 ms, 3 multiplier) so hijacked or flapping sessions drop quickly.
    • If your device lacks BFD, reduce BGP keep-alive/hold timers (30 / 90 s) instead of the defaults.
  5. monitor and alert
    • Stream Direct Connect BGP state change and RouteChange CloudWatch metrics; alarm on BGPPeerDown, MaxPrefixesExceeded, or unexpected ASN/path events.
    • Log all BGP syslog messages on the customer router to a SIEM and detect new or more-specific routes instantly.
  6. review quarterly
    • Compare advertised prefixes against your IPAM source of truth; prune any stale routes.
    • Rotate the BGP MD5 key when staff leave or devices are replaced.

These layered controlsauthentication, strict prefix/as-path filtering, and rapid failure detectiongreatly reduce the chance that an attacker can hijack your Direct Connect traffic or inject malicious routes.

References

  • AWS Direct Connect routing policies and BGP communities

reference.name: Security in AWS Direct Connect

countermeasure.name: Monitor and safeguard BGP routes
countermeasure.desc:
Continuously watch every Direct Connect BGP session and automatically flagor shut downany route change that could steer traffic to an unexpected destination.

  1. Stream BGP telemetry to CloudWatch
    • Enable the Direct Connect metrics BgpPeerState, BgpRouteFlapDampening, and BGPMaxPrefixesExceeded.
    • Create CloudWatch alarms that fire when a peer drops (BgpPeerState = 3), the route count jumps beyond the configured max-prefix value, or flapping exceeds a defined threshold.
  2. Log all route advertisements
    • On the customer router, export BGP UPDATE messages to a syslog or NetFlow collector; forward to your SIEM for real-time correlation.
    • Retain logs for at least 90 days so you can trace when and how a suspicious prefix entered the table.
  3. Detect drift with AWS Config & EventBridge
    • Deploy a custom AWS Config rule that compares the live list of accepted/advertised prefixes against your approved prefix list in IPAM.
    • When Config marks a resource NON_COMPLIANT, trigger an EventBridge rule that pages on-call staff andoptionallyruns an SSM Automation document to disable the virtual interface until reviewed.
  4. Implement route sanity checks
    • Use the routers prefix-list + route-map to drop any prefix longer than /24 or outside your owned CIDR blocks.
    • Set neighbor <peer-ip> maximum-prefix <N> restart 5 to halt a session that suddenly advertises too many routes.
  5. Visualise and review
    • Build a CloudWatch dashboard that shows current prefix count, peer state, and alarm status for every virtual interface.
    • Review logs and metrics weekly; investigate any new ASN in the AS-PATH or unexplained rise in prefix count.

Proactive monitoring combined with automatic drift detection stops hijacked, leaked, or mis-typed routes before they impact production traffic.

References

  • Monitoring Direct Connect BGP sessions with CloudWatch metrics
  • AWS Direct Connect routing policies and BGP communities

reference.name: Logging and monitoring in AWS Direct Connect

An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-682
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-682: Incorrect Calculation The product performs a calculation that generates incorrect or unintended results that are later used in security-critical decisions or resource management. When product performs a security-critical calculation incorrectly, it might lead to incorrect resource allocations, incorrect privilege assignments, or failed comparisons among other things. Many of the direct results of an incorrect calculation can lead to even larger problems such as failed protection mechanisms or even arbitrary code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-697
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-697: Incorrect Comparison The product compares two entities in a security-relevant context, but the comparison is incorrect, which may lead to resultant weaknesses.

countermeasure.name: Adopt capacity-aware, multi-Availability Zone placement strategies
countermeasure.desc:
Step-by-Step Guidance for Implementing the Countermeasure:

1. Use Multiple Instance Types and Launch Templates

To reduce potential disruptions caused by infrastructure limitations within a single Availability Zone (AZ), leverage multiple EC2 instance types and launch templates:

  • Analyze workload requirements to select compatible EC2 instance families/types that meet compute, memory, storage, and networking needs.
  • Create launch templates for each instance type, specifying key configuration details such as AMI, instance type, security group, and block device mappings. Follow AWS Launch Template Guidance for detailed instructions.
  • Test launch templates in your development environment to confirm compatibility and performance.

2. Configure Auto Scaling Groups Across Multiple Availability Zone Subnets

To achieve high availability and fault tolerance, distribute workloads across multiple subnets tied to different AZs.

  • Identify subnets associated with distinct AZs within your VPC. Ensure your VPC is configured correctly (Subnet Documentation).
  • Create or update Auto Scaling Groups (ASGs) to span these subnets, specifying multiple AZs during ASG configuration.
  • Set ASG scaling policies based on workload demand or health checks to dynamically allocate resources.

3. Monitor and Plan Service Quotas Per Availability Zone

AWS imposes quotas on resources per region and AZ, which can lead to capacity constraints. To avoid service disruptions:

  • Use the AWS Service Quotas dashboard to monitor quotas for critical resources like EC2 instances, EBS volumes, and Elastic IPs.
  • Plan resource allocations carefully while scaling across AZs and request quota increases as needed using AWS Service Quotas Console.
  • Automate monitoring of service quotas using Amazon CloudWatch.

4. Validate That Critical Workloads Can Start in Alternate Availability Zones

Ensure failover capabilities for critical workloads in case one AZ becomes unavailable:

  • Test the deployment of your applications in alternate AZs by simulating failure scenarios.
  • Review resource dependencies (e.g., EBS volumes and IP addresses) and ensure configurations allow for quick replication or reassignment in another AZ.
  • Create Disaster Recovery (DR) plans to guide workloads' transition within minutes of AZ disruptions.

5. Continuously Evaluate and Audit Configuration

Regularly audit your architecture and workload distribution across AZs to identify security and operational risks.

  • Use AWS Config to set up rules for continuous compliance checks.
  • Review AWS Trusted Advisor recommendations to optimize availability configurations and verify AZ balance.
  • Conduct routine penetration testing and failure drills for detecting vulnerabilities and validating failover mechanisms.

References

  • AWS EC2 Availability Zones Documentation
  • AWS Global Infrastructure
  • AWS EC2 Launch Templates
  • AWS Service Quotas
  • Amazon CloudWatch
  • AWS Config

countermeasure.name: Constrain egress per Availability Zone using NAT, routes, and endpoints
countermeasure.desc:
Step 1: Deploy NAT Gateways Per Availability Zone

To ensure high availability and fault tolerance, deploy a NAT Gateway in each Availability Zone within your VPC.

  • Navigate to the Amazon VPC console.
  • In the navigation pane, select NAT Gateways and then click Create NAT Gateway.
  • Select the subnet corresponding to the Availability Zone where the NAT Gateway will reside.
  • Allocate or select an Elastic IP address to associate with the NAT Gateway.
  • Repeat this process for all relevant Availability Zones in your VPC.

Step 2: Bind Private Subnets to Same-Zone NAT Gateways

Assign route tables to private subnets and ensure traffic destined for the internet is routed through NAT Gateways in the same Availability Zone.

  • In the Amazon VPC console, select Route Tables.
  • Choose a route table associated with a private subnet.
  • Edit routes to add a destination of 0.0.0.0/0 and set the target to the NAT Gateway's ID specific to the same Availability Zone.
  • Associate the route table with the private subnet in the Subnet Associations tab.
  • Repeat these steps for all private subnets to ensure zonal redundancy.

Step 3: Restrict Egress with Route Tables and Network ACLs

Limit the outbound traffic from private subnets to the minimum necessary to reduce the attack surface.

  • Configure the route table to direct only necessary traffic to specific destinations via the NAT Gateway.
  • Set up Network ACLs (NACLs) to explicitly allow specific protocols, ports, and IP ranges necessary for your applications.
  • Ensure a default "Deny" rule for other outbound traffic.

Step 4: Prefer VPC Endpoints for AWS Service Traffic

Leverage VPC endpoints (interface or gateway endpoints) to route traffic to AWS services directly within the AWS network, avoiding public internet routes.

  • Navigate to the Amazon VPC console and select Endpoints.
  • Click Create Endpoint and select the desired AWS service, such as S3 or DynamoDB.
  • Choose the appropriate Endpoint type (gateway or interface) based on the service.
  • Associate the endpoint with the relevant route tables within your VPC.
  • Test and verify traffic to AWS services flows through the endpoint instead of the NAT Gateway.

References

  • VPC Security Best Practices
  • Amazon VPC NAT Gateway Documentation
  • Amazon VPC Endpoints Documentation
  • Network ACLs Documentation

countermeasure.name: Design multi-Availability Zone architectures for fault isolation
countermeasure.desc:
To improve the security and resiliency of your workload in AWS, follow the step-by-step guidance below for distributing critical resources across multiple Availability Zones (AZs):

  1. Determine the number of Availability Zones and Regions: Analyze the workload requirements to identify suitable AWS Regions and the number of Availability Zones available in each Region. Refer to the AWS Availability Zone documentation to find detailed information.
  2. Create separate subnets for each Availability Zone: Design your Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) with subnets distributed across multiple AZs. Each AZ should have a dedicated subnet to ensure proper resource isolation and failover capabilities. Follow the guidelines in the AWS VPC User Guide for subnet creation.
  3. Configure Auto Scaling Groups across multiple subnets: Create an Auto Scaling Group (ASG) and specify the subnets in multiple AZs to ensure instances can launch in alternative AZs during an outage. Enable dynamic scaling policies to maintain a consistent level of performance. Review the AWS Auto Scaling documentation for step-by-step setup instructions.
  4. Use Multi-AZ deployments for managed services: For database services like Amazon RDS, enable Multi-AZ deployment to provision a standby replica in a secondary AZ. This setup automatically performs failover during disruptions. Additionally, validate Multi-AZ support for other managed services, such as Amazon ElastiCache and Amazon DynamoDB. Use the Amazon RDS Multi-AZ documentation for more information.
  5. Implement replication across Availability Zones: Configure data replication mechanisms that span AZs for critical datasets. For example, enable S3 cross-region replication or use the replication features provided by databases like Amazon DynamoDB Global Tables and Amazon Aurora. Reference the Amazon S3 Replication documentation.
  6. Validate failover and recovery processes: Conduct periodic failover testing to ensure seamless transitions during AZ outages. Validate that your Auto Scaling Groups, Multi-AZ services, and data replication mechanisms work as intended under simulated failure scenarios. Review AWS Well-Architected Framework guidelines for best practices.
  7. Monitor AZ health and implement alerts: Use AWS CloudWatch to monitor the performance and health of resources across AZs. Create alarms to detect anomalies or failures early, and set up SNS notifications to ensure real-time alerts for critical events. Refer to the Amazon CloudWatch documentation for guidance.
  8. Optimize cost and compliance considerations: Ensure your workload is distributed efficiently to avoid unnecessary costs while adhering to regional compliance requirements. Use AWS Cost Explorer and AWS Config to maintain visibility into cost and security configurations. Refer to the AWS Cost Explorer documentation.

References

  • AWS Availability Zones in EC2
  • AWS Global Infrastructure and Availability Zones
  • AWS VPC User Guide
  • Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling
  • Amazon RDS Multi-AZ
  • Amazon S3 Replication
  • AWS Well-Architected Framework
  • Amazon CloudWatch
  • AWS Cost Explorer

countermeasure.name: Harden per-Availability Zone network segmentation
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps to implement the security countermeasure for AWS Availability Zones effectively:

  1. Design the Subnet Architecture:
    • Create distinct public and private subnets in each Availability Zone within your VPC.
    • Ensure public subnets are used for resources requiring internet access, such as load balancers.
    • Place resources such as application servers or databases in private subnets to prevent direct internet exposure.
  2. Configure Security Groups:
    • Apply the principle of least privilege when creating and configuring security groups. Ensure they allow only explicitly required traffic.
    • Examples: Restrict access to application servers to specific IP ranges or allow database ports only from application servers.
    • Allocate separate security groups for different resource tiers (e.g., web, application, database).
  3. Set Up Network Access Control Lists (NACLs):
    • Create NACLs for subnets to define fine-grained network-level policies for inbound and outbound traffic.
    • Implement deny rules for traffic that must explicitly be blocked, alongside allowing necessary traffic.
    • Regularly review NACL rules to optimize security settings.
  4. Create Dedicated Route Tables:
    • Assign dedicated route tables for each subnet tier to ensure isolation and control over routing.
    • Public subnets route tables should include routes to an internet gateway (IGW), allowing internet-based communication.
    • Private subnets should have routes directing traffic through a NAT gateway or VPC endpoint, without routing traffic to the IGW.
  5. Leverage VPC Endpoints:
    • Use VPC endpoints to privately access AWS services such as S3, DynamoDB, or Systems Manager without the need for public internet access.
    • Subnet traffic directed to VPC endpoints will stay entirely within the AWS network, improving security.
    • Ensure proper IAM policies on the VPC endpoints to enforce access controls for the associated AWS service.
  6. Regularly Review Routes:
    • Inspect route tables periodically to identify any unintended routes that may expose resources to unauthorized access or create conflicts.
    • Remove unnecessary routes and test changes thoroughly before deployment.
    • Monitor changes in route tables using AWS Config to ensure compliance with your network security policies.

For further details and best practices, consult the following references:

  • VPC Security Best Practices
  • AWS Infrastructure Security Basics

countermeasure.name: Implement Availability Zone-scoped logging and monitoring
countermeasure.desc:
Step-by-Step Guidance for Implementing the Security Countermeasure:

1. Enable VPC Flow Logs for Each Subnet

VPC Flow Logs provide visibility into the IP traffic handled by your VPC. By enabling flow logs at the subnet level, you gain granular insights into traffic patterns and potential issues.

  • Log into the AWS Management Console.
  • Navigate to the VPC section of the console.
  • Select the target VPC and then locate the specific subnets within it.
  • Click on the subnet you want to enable logs for and choose Create Flow Log.
  • Specify the destination for the logs (e.g., CloudWatch Logs or an Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Choose appropriate filters (e.g., All, Accept, Reject).
  • Save your settings and repeat for all relevant subnets.

2. Enable AWS CloudTrail Across All Regions

AWS CloudTrail provides event history and auditing capabilities for actions occurring within your AWS account. You should ensure CloudTrail is globally enabled and centralized for all regions.

  • Navigate to the CloudTrail console.
  • Click Create trail.
  • Provide a name for your trail and enable logging across All Regions.
  • Specify where logs should be stored (e.g., an Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Configure optional encryption and permission settings for enhanced security.
  • Validate the trail creation and ensure monitoring is enabled for Availability Zone activity.

3. Centralize Logs in Amazon CloudWatch Metrics/Alarms

To gain insights into anomalous traffic behavior and monitor configuration drift, integrate logs with CloudWatch and set up metrics and alarms with dimensions for Availability Zones.

  • Navigate to the CloudWatch console.
  • Ensure you have enabled log ingestion from VPC Flow Logs and AWS CloudTrail.
  • Inside the console, create Log Groups to centralize logs related to traffic patterns in specific Availability Zones.
  • Define Metric Filters to extract key metrics from logs, such as large spikes in denied traffic or unexpected changes.
  • Create alarms using CloudWatch thresholds to alert when unusual behavior is identified.
  • Test alarms and validate their alignment with Availability Zone identifiers.

4. Continuously Monitor for Configuration Drift

Configuration drift occurs when the infrastructure gradually diverges from its intended state. Detect and mitigate it using AWS Config and automated corrective actions.

  • Enable AWS Config to monitor resource configurations across your account.
  • Use Config rules to track compliance with security best practices, focusing on VPC security, flow logs, and trail settings.
  • Create custom Config rules to log and alert for changes in subnet configurations or flow log status.
  • Integrate relevant insights into CloudWatch dashboards for centralized visibility.

5. Detect Anomalous Traffic Patterns

Leverage specific AWS tools to detect unusual or harmful traffic patterns across Availability Zones.

  • Integrate Amazon GuardDuty to analyze flow logs and CloudTrail events for threats.
  • Enable DNS threat detection and monitor unusual spikes or requests within Availability Zones.
  • Regularly audit metric alarms and identify high-traffic periods that dont correlate with expected behavior.
  • Implement runtime protection tools to respond to live traffic anomalies.

References

  • VPC Security Best Practices
  • AWS Infrastructure Security Basics
  • VPC Flow Logs User Guide
  • CloudTrail Console User Guide
  • Amazon CloudWatch Logs Monitoring
  • What Is AWS Config?
  • What is Amazon GuardDuty?

countermeasure.name: Restrict inter-Availability Zone connectivity with least privilege
countermeasure.desc:
To improve the security of AWS Availability Zone implementations, follow these comprehensive steps:

  1. Scope Security Group Rules to Necessary Ports and Sources:

    • Decide which ports are required based on the specific functionality of the application or workloads hosted within the Availability Zone.
    • Restrict inbound and outbound traffic to only the ranges of IPs or VPC resources that require access.
    • For each security group, use precise CIDR ranges or specific AWS resources (i.e., other security groups or instance IDs) to define allowed traffic. Ensure the rules comply with the principle of least privilege.
    • Review the configurations frequently to ensure that only necessary access is permitted and to detect any unused or overly permissive rules.
    • To implement, navigate to the Security Groups section in your AWS Management Console or use the AWS CLI/SDK.

  2. Segment Tiers per Availability Zone:

    • Design your application tiers (e.g., web, app, and database tiers) to align with specific Availability Zones. This provides a natural layer of segmentation for additional security.
    • Configure security group rules to ensure that lateral movement is restricted between tiers, except for explicitly required communication flows. For example, only allow the application tier to communicate with the database tier.
    • Use subnet segmentation within Availability Zones to isolate traffic dynamically based on the application tier's role. Each tier can be assigned its own subnet with distinct configurations.

  3. Use ALB/NLB Target Groups with Controlled Registration Across Zones:

    • Configure Target Groups in your Application Load Balancer (ALB) or Network Load Balancer (NLB) to register instances based on specific Availability Zones.
    • Verify that health checks are configured properly to ensure that only healthy instances are registered in Target Groups.
    • Control registration by tagging or labeling instances according to their purpose and zone, and create IAM policies or scripts for automated instance registration based on exclusion or inclusion criteria.
    • Use listener rules in your ALB or NLB to enforce zone-specific routing if necessary.

  4. Review NACLs to Minimize Lateral Movement:

    • For each subnet in your VPC, review Network Access Control List (NACL) rules to ensure that only legitimate traffic flows are allowed.
    • Block unnecessary intra-zone traffic by explicitly denying overly permissive rules, especially those allowing access between subnets of different tiers unnecessarily.
    • Use deny rules explicitly where feasible to block traffic that should not have lateral access across subnets and Availability Zones.
    • Regularly audit NACL rules using AWS Config to ensure compliance with best practices and monitor for drift or outdated configurations.

References

  • VPC Security Best Practices
  • Amazon EC2 Security Groups
  • What Is an Application Load Balancer?
  • Network Load Balancer Overview
  • Network ACL Overview
  • AWS Config Evaluation of Rules

countermeasure.name: Use stable Availability Zone ids and avoid hardcoded names
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure resources in AWS are distributed across distinct physical zones and maintain high availability, adhere to the following steps:

  1. Understand AWS Availability Zone IDs:
    • Availability Zones are distinct from "names" such as us-east-1a. These names vary per account due to internal mapping, but Availability Zone IDs (e.g., use-az1) remain consistent across accounts.
    • Refer to the AWS documentation on Availability Zone IDs to familiarize yourself with this concept: Availability Zone Concepts.
  2. Use Programmatic Discovery via the AWS CLI or SDK to dynamically retrieve Availability Zone information:
    • Run the following AWS CLI command to list all Availability Zones within a region:aws ec2 describe-availability-zones --region REGION_NAMEReplace REGION_NAME with your selected region (e.g., us-east-1).
    • In the output, reference the ZoneId fields (e.g., use-az1). These IDs can be used reliably to distribute resources across distinct physical locations.
  3. Automate Resource Spreading Across Zones:
    • Design your infrastructure to programmatically spread workloads across the unique ZoneId values using orchestration tools such as AWS CloudFormation, AWS SDK (for Python boto3 or Java SDK), or APIs.
    • Create deployment logic to verify that the resources are evenly distributed by cross-checking the ZoneId mappings during deployment or updates.
  4. Document the ZoneId mappings:
    • Maintain a record of Availability Zone IDs and their associated resources for each deployment or major change.
    • Store this documentation securely in a versioned repository or centralized configuration management system, such as AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store or an internal inventory system.
  5. Continuously Audit Resource Placement:
    • Periodically run the DescribeAvailabilityZones API or CLI command and validate the resource placement against the mapping records for consistency.
    • Update deployment documentation promptly if new zones are added or existing ones are modified.

References

  • Availability Zone Concepts
