usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Single Availability Zone dependency causing regional service outage impact
threat.desc:
General threat description
Workloads located in a single AWS Availability Zone are exposed to disruptions resulting from zonal failures, scheduled maintenance, or capacity constraints, posing risks to service continuity and data accessibility.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Zonal failures may arise from natural disasters, hardware malfunctions, or network issues. Planned maintenance or sudden demand spikes may also contribute to decreased availability.
Impacts
The impacts include potential outages, temporary or permanent loss of data, degradation of application performance, and loss of trust or revenue resulting from service disruptions.
Example Attack Scenarios
A hardware failure within an Availability Zone causes a widespread outage, bringing down critical applications hosted in that zone. Alternatively, a planned maintenance event reduces resource availability, resulting in service degradation for all workloads relying exclusively on that zone.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Availability Zone identifier mismatch across accounts causing misplacement
threat.desc:
General threat description
Hardcoding the names of Availability Zones can lead to resources being placed in unintended physical zones due to the variability in how names map to physical zones across accounts, which can compromise redundancy and failover strategies.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unintentional misconfiguration by developers or operators, reliance on incorrect documentation, or automated deployment scripts that do not account for differing zone mappings.
Impacts
Potential lack of high availability, increased risk of resource failure in disasters, and compromised system reliability due to violated redundancy and failover assumptions.
Example Attack Scenarios
A developer deploys instances to us-east-1a, assuming it corresponds to a specific physical zone across all accounts, but the mapping differs in their organizations AWS account, placing resources in the same physical zone as other critical systems. A failure in this zone leads to a cascading outage.

threat.name: Capacity and placement risk within an Availability Zone
threat.desc:
General threat description
Zonal capacity constraints or inflexible placement strategies can restrict the ability to scale or perform failovers during disruptions, leading to system downtime or reduced service availability.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Misconfigurations, resource limitations, or improper distribution of workloads can exacerbate zonal constraints and lack of effective placement mechanisms.
Impacts
Reduced service availability, inability to recover from disruptions, and potential customer dissatisfaction due to reliability issues.
Example Attack Scenarios
A sudden increase in resource demand overwhelms a specific Availability Zone, and the inability to migrate workloads to another zone results in degraded performance or service outages. Alternatively, rigid placement strategies restrict scalability, preventing efficient allocation of resources across zones during high loads.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Subnet and route misconfiguration exposing Availability Zone resources
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) design can lead to unintended exposure of instances or services within an Availability Zone to networks or the internet, compromising isolation and security.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit shared route tables, misconfigured public subnets meant to be private, or overly permissive network ACLs to gain unauthorized access or disrupt services.
Impacts
Potential impacts include data breaches, unauthorized access, service disruptions, or exploitation of exposed resources for malicious activities.
Example Attack Scenarios
An organization accidentally configures a public subnet instead of a private one, inadvertently exposing critical services to the internet. Attackers notice and exploit misconfigured ACLs to access sensitive data or disrupt internal services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

threat.name: Cross-Availability Zone traffic exposure due to broad network rules
threat.desc:
General threat description
Overly permissive configurations in security groups or network ACLs can inadvertently create unintended cross-Availability Zone access paths, potentially increasing the impact of a compromise and expanding the blast radius.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors or misconfigured resources can exploit permissive settings to traverse networks across zones, accessing unauthorized systems or data in other Availability Zones.
Impacts
Unauthorized access can lead to data breaches, service disruptions, and escalation of security incidents across multiple zones, reducing the isolation benefits of Availability Zones.
Example Attack Scenarios
A misconfigured database in one zone with an overly permissive security group gets exploited by an attacker, who then pivots to access sensitive systems in other zones through unintended network paths, amplifying the impact of the event.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1133 - External Remote Services

threat.name: Uncontrolled internet egress from Availability Zone subnets
threat.desc:
General threat description
Instances in private subnets of an Availability Zone may inadvertently access the internet through shared NAT gateways or misconfigured routing, potentially exposing them to risks such as data exfiltration or unauthorized command-and-control activities if outbound traffic is not strictly controlled per zone.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit misconfigured routing tables, overly permissive NAT gateway rules, or unmonitored outbound traffic within the private subnets to establish unauthorized communication channels with external entities.
Impacts
Compromise of sensitive data, unauthorized remote control of instances, or exploitation of the infrastructure for malicious activity, which could lead to financial, reputational, and operational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker might exploit a misconfigured routing table to redirect traffic from instances to a malicious server on the internet, extracting sensitive information. Alternatively, compromised instances could use a shared NAT gateway to contact a command-and-control server, initiating further attacks or lateral movement within the environment.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol

usecase.name: Lateral Movement
usecase.desc: Lateral Movement refers to the technique used by attackers to move horizontally across a network after gaining initial access. Once inside a network, attackers seek to explore and compromise additional systems to escalate their attack and access valuable resources.

threat.name: Insufficient Availability Zone-aware logging and visibility
threat.desc:
General threat description
Insufficient logging and monitoring granularity associated with Availability Zones can hinder prompt identification and management of zonal faults, unauthorized lateral movement, or configuration errors, weakening the efficacy of incident response.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers exploiting gaps in logging to move laterally between zones or leveraging undetected misconfigurations to compromise security.
Impacts
Delayed detection of security concerns, reduced incident response times, and increased potential for extensive damage or data breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
An undetected misconfiguration in one zone allows unauthorized access, and the lack of granular monitoring enables an attacker to move laterally to compromise other zones without being noticed.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1210 - Exploitation of Remote Services

component.name: Subnet
component.desc: Represents a Subnet within the VPC.

weakness.name: CWE-272
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-272: Least Privilege Violation The elevated privilege level required to perform operations such as chroot() should be dropped immediately after the operation is performed.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Apply least privilege security groups
countermeasure.desc:
To minimize attack surface and prevent unauthorized access, restrict Security Group rules to only the ports, protocols, and source CIDRs your workload requires. This ensures that only legitimate traffic can reach your instances, reducing risk of compromise or lateral movement within your VPC.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Identify required traffic: Document exactly which ports, protocols, and IP ranges your application needs for inbound and outbound communication.
  2. Tighten Security Group rules: Update each Security Group so that inbound and outbound rules specify only those required ports and source/destination CIDRsavoid using 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0 unless absolutely necessary.
  3. Use security group references: Where possible, reference other Security Groups instead of IP ranges to scope access to known AWS resources.
  4. Automate enforcement: Deploy AWS Config managed rulerestricted-security-groups (or a custom rule) to continuously detect overly permissive rules, and incorporate rule checks into your IaC templates (CloudFormation, Terraform).
  5. Review and audit regularly: Schedule periodic reviews of all Security Group rules to ensure they remain aligned with current application requirements and remove any stale or unused rules.

References:

  • Control traffic to your AWS resources using security groups

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

countermeasure.name: Implement AWS Shield
countermeasure.desc:
To protect your subnet resources from volumetric and applicationlayer denialofservice (DDoS) attacks, implement AWS Shield to automatically detect and mitigate malicious traffic. This ensures high availability by absorbing or blocking attack traffic before it impacts your instances.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Enable AWS Shield Standard: Shield Standard is enabled by default at no extra cost for all AWS customers confirm coverage for your Elastic IPs, Application Load Balancers, and CloudFront distributions.
  2. Subscribe to AWS Shield Advanced (optional): For enhanced protection, enable Shield Advanced in the AWS Shield console, choose the resources (Elastic IPs, ALBs, NLBs, Global Accelerators) you want to protect, and accept the service terms.
  3. Configure DDoS response settings: If using Shield Advanced, grant AWS DDoS Response Team (DRT) access to your account for emergency assistance, and set up proactive notifications.
  4. Monitor metrics and alarms: Use CloudWatch metrics (e.g.,DDoSDetected, AttackVolume) to track attack activity and create alarms to trigger automated responses (AWS WAF ratebased rules, autoscaling actions).
  5. Review protection reports: Regularly review Shield Advanced attack diagnostics and cost protection reports to validate coverage and adjust resource configurations as needed.

References:

  • AWS Shield Advanced API Reference

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.DS-4: Adequate capacity to ensure availability is maintained
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1031 - Network Intrusion Prevention

countermeasure.name: Restrict outbound traffic
countermeasure.desc:
To prevent unauthorized data exfiltration and reduce risk of communicating with malicious endpoints, restrict subnet egress traffic to only approved destinations using Network ACL outbound rules and AWS PrivateLink.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Define approved destinations: Create a whitelist of trusted external IP ranges, domains, and AWS service endpoints required by your workloads.
  2. Configure Network ACL outbound rules: In each subnets NACL, add explicit ALLOW rules for only the approved IP addresses and ports. Set a final DENY rule (0.0.0.0/0) to block all other egress traffic.
  3. Use AWS PrivateLink for AWS services: Replace direct internet access to AWS services (S3, DynamoDB, etc.) with PrivateLink endpoints to keep traffic on the AWS network and avoid exposure to the public internet.
  4. Validate with AWS Config: Enable the managed rulenetwork-acl-traffic-check (or a custom rule) to detect overly permissive outbound rules.
  5. Monitor and audit: Regularly review VPC Flow Logs for denied egress attempts and update NACL rules or PrivateLink endpoints as application requirements evolve.

References:

  • Control subnet traffic with network access control lists

countermeasure.name: Restrict subnet routing
countermeasure.desc:
Prevent resources in private subnets from being directly reachable fromor reachingthe public internet by removing any 0.0.0.0/0 route to an Internet Gateway in their route tables and disabling automatic assignment of public IPv4 addresses. This reduces exposure of sensitive workloads and enforces a clear separation between public and private network tiers.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Identify all subnets designated as private in your VPC.
  2. For each private subnets route table, verify there is no route entry with destination 0.0.0.0/0 (or ::/0) pointing to an Internet Gateway (igw*). Remove any such routes if present.
  3. In the AWS Console or via IaC (CloudFormation/Terraform), disable Auto-assign public IPv4 address for each private subnet.
  4. Deploy the AWS Config managed rulevpc-no-public-ip (CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark 4.1) to continuously check that private subnets do not autoassign public IPs.
  5. Schedule periodic audits of subnet route tables and subnet settings to ensure no drift from this configuration.

References:

  • How Amazon VPC works

countermeasure.name: Review route tables
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure each subnets route table contains only the routes required for its intended function. Regular audits help you detect and remove accidental or malicious route additions (such as unintended Internet Gateway, NAT Gateway, or VPC peering routes) that could expose private resources or misroute traffic.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Inventory route tables: List all route tables and their associated subnets using the AWS Console, CLI (aws ec2 describe-route-tables), or IaC outputs.
  2. Define approved routes baseline: Document the expected destination CIDRs and targets (e.g., NAT Gateway, Transit Gateway) for each subnet type (public, private, isolated).
  3. Compare actual vs. baseline: Use automated scripts or AWS Config to identify route entries that dont match the approved baseline.
  4. Remove unauthorized routes: Immediately delete any unexpected or overly broad routes (for example, 0.0.0.0/0 pointing to an Internet Gateway in a private subnet).
  5. Automate continuous auditing: Enable the AWS Config managed rule vpc-route-table-association-check or create a custom AWS Config rule to flag noncompliant routes.
  6. Schedule periodic reviews: Conduct manual or automated reviews at least quarterly and after major infrastructure changes to validate route configurations.

References:

  • Configure route tables

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Attackers flood subnet resources
threat.desc:
General threat description
A subnet flood attack overwhelms AWS subnet network capacity by sending excessive traffic to resources, causing service slowdowns or outages.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • External botnets launching volumetric DDoS
  • Compromised EC2 instances generating internal traffic storms
  • Reflection/amplification via open UDP services

Impacts

  • Service downtime or degraded performance
  • Higher AWS data transfer and scaling costs
  • Increased incident response effort

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A botnet floods a public subnets Internet Gateway with SYN packets, blocking legitimate web traffic.
  • An attacker spoofs the subnets IP in DNS amplification queries, inundating instances with amplified responses.
  • A compromised EC2 instance inside a private subnet floods other instances with traffic, exhausting network throughput.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1498 - Network Denial of Service

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers exfiltrate sensitive data
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers exfiltrate sensitive data by moving confidential information out of an AWS subnet to unauthorized destinations.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Compromised EC2 instances or containers leaking data
  • Misconfigured outbound security group or NACL rules
  • Malware using allowed outbound protocols (HTTPS, SFTP)

Impacts

  • Loss of intellectual property or customer data
  • Regulatory noncompliance fines
  • Reputational damage

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A compromised application server in a private subnet sends database backups to an attackers external S3 bucket via AWS CLI.
  • Malware on an EC2 instance uses permitted HTTPS to upload sensitive files to a remote commandandcontrol server.
  • Misconfigured security group allows unrestricted outbound FTP, enabling bulk transfer of PII to a malicious host.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel

threat.name: Attackers redirect network traffic
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers redirect network traffic by manipulating route configurations or DNS settings in a subnet, causing legitimate data flows to be sent through unauthorized or malicious endpoints.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Malicious or compromised IAM principals altering route tables
  • Compromised NAT gateways or VPC endpoints used as rogue proxies
  • DNS misconfiguration or poisoning via Route 53

Impacts

  • Interception or modification of sensitive data (MITM)
  • Loss of data integrity and confidentiality
  • Service disruptions from misrouted traffic

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker with compromised credentials adds a route in a private subnets route table directing all traffic through a compromised EC2 instance acting as a proxy.
  • A misconfigured Route 53 private hosted zone points internal service names to an attackercontrolled IP, diverting requests.
  • A compromised NAT gateway is reconfigured to forward outbound traffic through an external server, exposing data in transit.

threat.name: Attackers reach public instances
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers reach public instances when misconfigured routing or security rules expose EC2 resources in a public subnet directly to the internet, allowing unauthorized access.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Internetbased scanners and bruteforce bots
  • Exploitation of open ports (SSH, RDP, HTTP)
  • Weak or reused credentials

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to systems and data
  • Potential deployment of malware or ransomware
  • Lateral movement into the VPC

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A misconfigured security group permits SSH from any IP; attackers bruteforce credentials to gain shell access.
  • An open RDP port on a public EC2 instance is discovered by a scanning bot and used to install a backdoor.
  • An unpatched web server in a public subnet is exploited via a known vulnerability to steal data and pivot internally.

usecase.name: Lateral Movement
usecase.desc: Lateral Movement refers to the technique used by attackers to move horizontally across a network after gaining initial access. Once inside a network, attackers seek to explore and compromise additional systems to escalate their attack and access valuable resources.

threat.name: Attackers traverse internal network
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers traverse internal network when overly permissive security rules allow them to move laterally between resources within a subnet or across subnets, increasing scope of compromise.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Compromised EC2 instances or containers
  • Broad Security Group rules permitting unrestricted internal traffic
  • Weak or missing Network ACL restrictions

Impacts

  • Escalation of privileges and broader system compromise
  • Theft or corruption of sensitive data across multiple resources
  • Longer detection and remediation times

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker breaches a web server in a private subnet, then uses SSH to connect to a database server because its security group allows all internal IPs.
  • Malware on one EC2 instance scans and infects neighboring instances via open internal ports.
  • A misconfigured NACL allows all traffic within a VPC, enabling an attacker to pivot from a lowvalue test instance to a production application server.

component.name: Virtual or Transit Gateway
component.desc: Virtual or Transit Gateway for network connectivity.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-233
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-233: Improper Handling of Parameters The product does not properly handle when the expected number of parameters, fields, or arguments is not provided in input, or if those parameters are undefined.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-476
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-476: NULL Pointer Dereference A NULL pointer dereference occurs when the application dereferences a pointer that it expects to be valid, but is NULL, typically causing a crash or exit. NULL pointer dereference issues can occur through a number of flaws, including race conditions, and simple programming omissions.

weakness.name: CWE-862
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-862: Missing Authorization The product does not perform an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

countermeasure.name: Assign unique Autonomous System Numbers (ASN) for each Transit Gateway in multi-region deployments
countermeasure.desc: In multi-Region deployments, assign a unique Autonomous System Number (ASN) to each AWS Transit Gateway to prevent routing conflicts. This ensures that the routing tables between Regions remain independent, avoiding the risk of misrouted traffic or network instability. Use the AWS Management Console or CLI to configure distinct ASNs for each Transit Gateway during setup. Regularly audit the ASN assignments across Regions to maintain routing consistency and avoid conflicts that could impact network performance.

Ensure route propagation is enabled for all BGP Site-to-Site VPN and Direct Connect attachments in AWS Transit Gateway to maintain proper routing and network stability. In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the Transit Gateway route tables and verify that route propagation is turned on for these connections. This ensures that dynamic routing changes are automatically updated and applied, preventing traffic loss or disruptions due to misconfigured routes. Regularly audit route configurations to ensure continued compliance.

countermeasure.name: Implement redundant Transit Gateway per region for disaster recovery
countermeasure.desc: Deploy a single AWS Transit Gateway per Region to ensure redundancy and support disaster recovery. This avoids a single point of failure and improves overall network availability. Use multiple Transit Gateways in different Regions to distribute traffic and provide failover capabilities in case of regional outages. Configure route tables and VPC attachments in each Region to ensure seamless communication. Regularly test the disaster recovery setup to verify that failover mechanisms are functioning as expected.

Ensure that only necessary route tables are in place to simplify network management and improve traffic efficiency. Regularly audit the routing setup for optimization opportunities.

countermeasure.name: Update both VPCs simultaneously during migrations to avoid MTU mismatches
countermeasure.desc: During VPC migrations, ensure both VPCs are updated simultaneously to prevent mismatches in Maximum Transmission Unit (MTU) settings. Mismatched MTUs can cause packet drops and network disruptions. Use the AWS Management Console or automation tools to coordinate updates between VPCs, ensuring that both VPCs are configured with matching MTU settings. This helps maintain seamless traffic flow and reduces the risk of packet loss. Regularly monitor network performance to detect and resolve any MTU-related issues.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Suboptimal traffic flow due to multiple route tables
threat.desc:
General threat description
Using multiple Transit Gateway route tables unnecessarily can result in inefficient traffic routing, increasing latency and complicating network management. This can degrade performance and lead to unoptimized traffic flows across the network.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Agents: Network architects, cloud administrators.
  • Vectors: Overuse or misconfiguration of multiple route tables in Transit Gateway, leading to inefficient routing.

Impacts

  • Increased latency and inefficient routing.
  • Complex network management with potential misconfigurations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Multiple route tables cause traffic to take longer paths, increasing latency between VPCs.
  2. Inefficient route propagation across multiple tables results in suboptimal traffic flows, impacting application performance.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Improper route propagation
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper route propagation occurs when routing tables between AWS Transit Gateway and connected VPCs or on-premises networks are misconfigured, leading to failed or suboptimal routing of traffic. This can disrupt network communication, causing traffic to be dropped or misrouted.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Agents: Network administrators, cloud architects.
  • Vectors: Incorrect configuration of routing tables, failure to enable route propagation between BGP VPNs or Direct Connect.

Impacts

  • Service disruption due to traffic routing failures.
  • Increased latency or total loss of connectivity.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A misconfigured route table prevents traffic from being routed between VPCs, causing service outages.
  2. Failure to enable route propagation for a Direct Connect gateway leads to on-premises applications losing connectivity to AWS resources.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations||ATT&CK ICS - T0841 - Network Service Scanning

threat.name: Asymmetric traffic due to MTU mismatch
threat.desc:
General threat description
Asymmetric traffic occurs when differing Maximum Transmission Unit (MTU) settings between AWS Transit Gateway and connected VPCs or on-premises networks cause packet loss or drops. This mismatch can disrupt network communications, leading to degraded performance or total loss of connectivity.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Agents: Network administrators, misconfigured routers, cloud migrations.
  • Vectors: MTU size discrepancies during cloud-to-cloud or hybrid migrations, inadequate MTU settings between VPCs and on-premises networks.

Impacts

  • Packet loss and degraded performance in communication between AWS resources.
  • Connectivity disruptions leading to application outages or user dissatisfaction.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. During a VPC migration, inconsistent MTU settings between Transit Gateway and VPC peering lead to packet drops, causing application failures.
  2. An on-premises network with mismatched MTU settings with AWS Transit Gateway suffers from slow data transmission and dropped connections.

threat.name: ASN conflicts in multi-region setups
threat.desc:
General threat description
Autonomous System Number (ASN) conflicts can arise when the same ASN is used for multiple AWS Transit Gateways in a multi-Region deployment. This can lead to routing conflicts, causing traffic misrouting or network disruptions.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Agents: Network architects, cloud administrators.
  • Vectors: Use of identical ASN values across Transit Gateways in different Regions.

Impacts

  • Routing conflicts leading to service disruptions or misrouted traffic.
  • Increased complexity in diagnosing and resolving network issues.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Two Transit Gateways in different Regions using the same ASN result in routing loops, disrupting cross-region connectivity.
  2. Identical ASN values cause routing conflicts between on-premises networks and AWS, leading to failed data transfers.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578 - Modify Cloud Compute Infrastructure

threat.name: Single point of failure in multi-region deployments
threat.desc:
General threat description
A single point of failure occurs when only one AWS Transit Gateway is deployed in a multi-Region setup. If the gateway fails, the entire network across multiple Regions could be disrupted, leading to service outages and loss of connectivity.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Agents: Misconfigured network design, lack of redundancy.
  • Vectors: Failure of the single Transit Gateway due to hardware, software, or configuration issues.

Impacts

  • Complete network outage across multiple Regions.
  • Loss of service availability and business continuity.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A Transit Gateway fails due to an AWS infrastructure issue, causing network traffic between Regions to halt.
  2. A misconfigured Transit Gateway leads to a failure in routing traffic between Regions, resulting in downtime for critical services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Control traffic using network ACLs
countermeasure.desc: Manage inbound and outbound traffic at the subnet level by configuring network Access Control Lists (ACLs) in your VPC. Network ACLs act as stateless firewalls for your subnets, allowing you to set rules that permit or deny traffic based on IP protocol, port number, and source/destination IP address. To implement this, navigate to the VPC section in the AWS Management Console, create or modify network ACLs, and associate them with the appropriate subnets. Regularly review and update ACL rules to enhance security and compliance.

countermeasure.name: Detect potential threats with Amazon GuardDuty
countermeasure.desc: Enable Amazon GuardDuty to continuously monitor VPC flow logs for malicious activity and potential security threats. GuardDuty uses machine learning and threat intelligence to analyze traffic patterns and detect anomalies. To implement this, activate GuardDuty in the AWS Management Console, configure it to ingest VPC flow logs, DNS logs, and CloudTrail event logs. Regularly review GuardDuty findings and take appropriate actions to mitigate identified threats, ensuring your VPC remains secure against evolving attack vectors.

countermeasure.name: Distribute subnets across multiple availability zones
countermeasure.desc: To ensure high availability, fault tolerance, and scalability of your applications hosted on Amazon VPC, create subnets in multiple Availability Zones (AZs) within the same AWS Region. An Availability Zone comprises one or more data centers with independent power, networking, and connectivity. By distributing subnets across multiple AZs, you can mitigate the risk of a single point of failure and enhance the resilience of your application against potential outages or failures in a single AZ. This approach provides redundancy and improves overall system reliability.

countermeasure.name: Enable VPC flow logs
countermeasure.desc: Implement VPC flow logs to capture information about the IP traffic going to and from network interfaces within your VPC. This log data can help you monitor network traffic, identify potential security threats, diagnose network issues, and ensure compliance with regulatory requirements. To enable VPC Flow Logs, navigate to the VPC section in the AWS Management Console, select your VPC, and create a new Flow Log, specifying the destination for the log data, such as Amazon CloudWatch Logs or an S3 bucket. Regularly review and analyze these logs for abnormal traffic patterns and security incidents.

AWS Network Firewall provides stateful, managed network firewall and intrusion prevention services to safeguard your VPC from malicious activity. To implement it, create a firewall in the AWS Management Console, configure rules to control inbound and outbound traffic, and associate the firewall with your VPC subnets. Regularly update and monitor these rules to ensure they align with your security policies and threat landscape.

Regularly review and update IAM policies to maintain security best practices and compliance.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Single point of failure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

A Single Point of Failure (SPOF) refers to a critical component or node within a system whose failure can cause the entire system to stop functioning. In a cloud environment like Amazon VPS, this can result from configuring all resources within a single Availability Zone (AZ), leading to potential outages if that zone experiences issues.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Natural disasters affecting a specific AZ.
  • Technical failures such as power outages, network issues, or hardware malfunctions within the AZ.
  • Cyberattacks targeting the infrastructure of a specific AZ.

Impacts

  • Downtime and service disruptions.
  • Loss of availability for applications and services.
  • Potential data loss or corruption.
  • Financial losses due to service outages and recovery costs.
  • Reputational damage due to service unreliability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Natural Disaster: A severe storm impacts the data center in a single AZ, causing all services hosted in that zone to become unavailable.
  2. Technical Failure: A power outage in the data center leads to downtime for all resources configured solely in that AZ.
  3. Cyberattack: A targeted DDoS attack overwhelms the infrastructure of a single AZ, resulting in service disruption for all resources within that zone.

To mitigate this threat, it is recommended to distribute resources across multiple Availability Zones, ensuring redundancy and high availability.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized network access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized network access occurs when individuals or entities gain access to a network without permission, potentially leading to data breaches, service disruption, and exploitation of resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers using methods such as brute force or exploitation of vulnerabilities.
  • Internal malicious actors exploiting legitimate access.
  • Misconfigurations in security settings, such as overly permissive security groups or network ACLs.

Impacts

  • Data theft and loss of sensitive information.
  • Service disruptions and potential downtime.
  • Increased risk of further network and system exploitation.
  • Financial losses and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. External Attack: A hacker gains unauthorized access to an EC2 instance by exploiting a vulnerability in a web application and subsequently accessing the underlying network.
  2. Internal Misuse: An employee uses their legitimate access to explore unauthorized network segments, leading to potential data exfiltration.
  3. Misconfiguration: A misconfigured security group allows inbound traffic from any IP address, enabling an attacker to exploit services running within the VPC.

To mitigate this threat, enforce strict access controls using security groups and network ACLs, regularly review and update security configurations, and employ network monitoring tools to detect and respond to unauthorized access attempts promptly.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Insufficient monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insufficient monitoring refers to the lack of adequate surveillance and tracking mechanisms to detect, log, and analyze activities within a system. In Amazon VPS, this can lead to undetected security incidents, compliance issues, and operational inefficiencies.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Hackers exploiting unmonitored vulnerabilities.
  • Internal malicious actors taking advantage of weak logging practices.
  • Unintended configuration changes going unnoticed.

Impacts

  • Delayed or missed detection of security breaches.
  • Increased risk of data theft or corruption.
  • Non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
  • Prolonged downtime and extended incident response times.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Data Breach: A hacker gains unauthorized access to a VPS due to a missed security patch, which goes unnoticed due to insufficient monitoring.
  2. Internal Threat: An employee with elevated privileges accesses sensitive data without proper logging, making it difficult to trace the action.
  3. Configuration Error: Misconfigurations in security groups or network ACLs are not detected, leading to potential exposure of resources.

To address this threat, it is crucial to implement comprehensive monitoring solutions like AWS CloudWatch and AWS CloudTrail, and to regularly review and analyze logs to identify and respond to potential security incidents promptly.

threat.name: Unintended network access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unintended network access occurs when resources within a network are inadvertently exposed to unauthorized entities due to misconfigurations or oversight, leading to potential data breaches, unauthorized modifications, and service disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting exposed services.
  • Internal users accessing unintended resources due to misconfigured permissions.
  • Automated scripts or tools scanning for open ports and services.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data.
  • Service disruptions and operational inefficiencies.
  • Increased risk of further exploitation and lateral movement within the network.
  • Financial and reputational damage due to data breaches and service outages.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Exposed Services: A database is unintentionally left accessible from the internet due to misconfigured security groups, allowing an attacker to access and exfiltrate sensitive data.
  2. Internal Access: An employee accesses confidential files stored in an improperly secured S3 bucket that should have been restricted.
  3. Automated Scans: An automated tool finds an open management port on an EC2 instance, which is then exploited to gain unauthorized access.

To mitigate this threat, regularly review and update security group rules, network ACLs, and use tools like AWS Network Access Analyzer to identify and rectify unintended network exposures.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

threat.name: Unfiltered traffic
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unfiltered traffic refers to network traffic that is not adequately controlled or monitored, allowing potentially harmful data to enter or exit the network unchecked. This can lead to security vulnerabilities, data breaches, and network inefficiencies in an Amazon VPS environment.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers sending malicious data packets.
  • Internal users inadvertently or deliberately bypassing security measures.
  • Misconfigured security groups and network ACLs allowing all traffic.

Impacts

  • Exposure to malware and other malicious content.
  • Data exfiltration or loss of sensitive information.
  • Network congestion and reduced performance.
  • Increased risk of further network exploitation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Malware Infiltration: An attacker sends malicious traffic that goes unchecked into the network, infecting servers and spreading malware.
  2. Data Exfiltration: An internal user sends sensitive data out of the network due to lack of outbound traffic filtering.
  3. DoS Attack: Unfiltered inbound traffic leads to a Denial of Service attack, overwhelming the network and causing service outages.

To mitigate this threat, implement and regularly update security groups, network ACLs, and use AWS Network Firewall to filter and monitor inbound and outbound traffic.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Compromised IAM credentials
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Compromised IAM (Identity and Access Management) credentials refer to instances where attackers gain unauthorized access to AWS resources by obtaining valid IAM credentials. This can lead to significant security breaches, unauthorized data access, and control over AWS services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Phishing attacks to trick users into revealing credentials.
  • Brute force attacks to guess passwords.
  • Exploitation of weak password policies.
  • Insider threats where employees misuse access privileges.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data and resources.
  • Potential data breaches and data loss.
  • Unauthorized modifications or deletions of resources.
  • Financial losses due to misuse of AWS services.
  • Reputational damage from security incidents.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Phishing Attack: An attacker sends a phishing email to an employee, tricking them into providing their IAM credentials, which are then used to access and extract data from S3 buckets.
  2. Brute Force Attack: An attacker uses automated tools to repeatedly attempt logins until they successfully guess a weak password, gaining unauthorized access to critical resources.
  3. Insider Threat: A disgruntled employee uses their IAM credentials to access sensitive information and leak it to external parties.

To mitigate this threat, enforce strong password policies, enable multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all IAM users, regularly rotate credentials, and monitor IAM activities using AWS CloudTrail and AWS Config for unusual access patterns.
